DIV1.P: The Knave in Graine, New Vampt. A witty Comedy, Acted at the Fortune many dayes to∣gether with great Applause. Written by J. D. Gent.
LONDON: Printed by J. O. and are to be sold by John Nicholson at his Shop under St. Martins Church neare Ludgate. 1640.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Generous Reader.
DIV1.P: COurteous Reader, the ancient Latin Adage is, Sul∣torum, but I say Nebulonum plena sunt omnia, Knaves be about all persons, and in all places. There are twelve Coat-Cards in the bunch, of which foure are Knaves, Heart, Diamond, Spade, Club, suiting with the foure C C C C: Court, City, Country, Campe: My purpose is not to touch any in particular; onely thus much of them in generall: some are notable, some notori∣ous, some pimping, some panderly Knaves; some prating, some pestilent; some cousening, some cunny-catching Knaves. There are also lazy and lying, base, and deboist, fantasticall, foolish, and false Knaves. To these we may adde Hereticall and Hypocriti∣call, schismaticall, and separisticall Knaves: not forgetting perjur'd, and shamelesse; impudent, and informing; arrogant, and arrant Knaves, Cum multis alijs. And besides these, I have heard of a Knave Tapster, a Knave Ostler, a Knave Ser∣jeant, and a Knave Broker: but with these we have nothing to doe at this time; onely with a Knave in graine, or a Knave new vampt, in decyphering of whom, I give all the rest this Caveat, Have amongst you my Masters: And now if any of the rest shall finde himselfe touch't, hee hath his mends in his owne hands, for he cannot say but I gave him faire warning. And so much of the Argument, the Act followes.

LIST.ITEM: A rabble of Boyes and o∣thers.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus primus. Scena prima.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: WHy how now Puss, what ayles my Monkie to chatter out of tune thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: A whoreson sencelesse Cox∣combe— but I am glad th'art come, I long for a pottle of wine and a Capon.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Good provision for the pre∣sent Monkie, but viderit futuritas, in the meane time, who layes up for futu∣rity? Come you raise foure hundred per annum, out of pottles of Wine and Capons?

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: Yes my Granado, in this qualitie: they that come short of my breeding have don't. The first credit I wonne was in a Garrison.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: In Holland.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: No; and yet in the low Countries: I never sate foot in a leaguer yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: The reason of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: My hard fate nothing else, having as much impu∣dence, and as many wayes to manage it, receiving weekly Corantoes from Paris, Roterdam, and Flushing, and having trade too in Middleborough, I have beene house Lecturer three yeares together, and read Aretine, both in print and picture, and that is much for one of my yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: 'T may be thou wantst acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: No such matter, the old Exchange, the new Burse, and new Town, afford plenty; not a Prentice that can cry Bawd, nor a Butchers Dog that can say bow wow, but is of my acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Yet it may be they are precise, and will not be seen in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: That I know not, but most sure, I have feasted the Liberty twice at mine owne charge, and helpt their wives and daughters to the earning of many a fair pound: they will be seen in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Well, I am sure I have furnish'd thy Library with all books of behaviour, and tables of entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: And I have cull'd out all my phrases as curiously & stuck my language with such inticing conveniences: and for intellicence, all the lawn women, lace women, box women, and to come nearer to the businesse, very haire women, per∣riwig women, and candied Elicumpany lick halbars, come in twice a week like decoy Ducks, with whole sholes at the aile of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Why, then there's a fault in your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: I, I, that villanous company undoes all, Ther's Lo∣dowick Tomaso Vallentine, high talkers, and deepe drinkers, but they have wit in their wine, and too much honesty in their actions at all time, there's only on Gentleman—

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Stultissimo of a plain cut and square size, he runs just as you throw him; rub him a little against the grain now, and he will come off a great deal the smoother. You would not thinke, what charitable benefactours three or foure such plush Colonels would be to the founding of a new ho∣nour.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: But hast thou such a purpose, indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Why should not I have purpose and effect as much as any: A leager, yes, so it lay in the Ile of plentie; Ide dig through the Alpes with Haniball, and fetch Theseus from Hell, with Hercules purpose and practice, my precious Monkie, tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: And shall I come to the honour to write Mistris of the Leaguer.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Shall not bate an accent of that title my Catampti∣all Monky, but you must look out for Spiders Monky, and the Sprall of all foure Puzz: I have laid the foundation in gold already.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: Hast had a good return of thy Rings chuck?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Rings hangum, they are as stale as Scotch Lanson, Or as your Decoy,
No, I have sent um out in a desperat venture to Cape.
No Monkie, my old friend Franciscus hath repaired my Jacket already, & has promised to new thatch my outside too.
One of these boxes has 100 pieces of new gold,
With chains and keyes correspondent.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.P: For what use Chick?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: For a dead lift Monkie: a Leaguer cannot be plan∣ted, mann'd, victuall'd and munition'd with a small Maga∣zine: to work Monkie, a mouzing Puss, make choice of your company, admit no parley with the popular, be high and proud of thy selfe, and let those that will needs buy thee, pay soundly for thee with a pox to um, Puss a wink to the wise, you know my minde, let's have no more midnight catter∣wowlings under Sale-mens shop windows, Vintners dark cellers, no Justices long Entries, but beare up your selfe so civill and so meager▪
You may be stilde a sister of the Leaguer.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Dulciflora a Whore, and Mistris Durable a Bawd, old Signior Stultissimo a foolish Gentleman, and Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Away you Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: As I am a Gentleman body and soule Ile break your windowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Master, as you are a man stand and tickle her.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Will you, you Rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: Ah, sweet heart, prethee good woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Nay, let her come Ile give her hert belly full.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Let her alone Fub: let her alone, by this hand, Ile make the boyes maule her Ruffs.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Fie how I am tyred a whorson stinking shamleg'd, Fie, fie, fie, use a Gentlewoman thus in her own lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: How does your back, O the Fucas, out alas, here's half a Crown in Complexion utterly cast away.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: If I be not even with the Rutter—

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: If hee come where you have to doe, let him pay soundly.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: A plague upon his Asses eares, by my Virginity, Ile send his beard into New-found-land for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: And so I would, to make lines to catch Cods: out, out, out, a Gentleman, and use a woman no otherwise; yfaith, yfath, it stands not with his reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: A whorson smelt: Mistris Durable, I would I had some of your aqua vitae, I'me sick after the conflict.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: And shall good woman, come, come, pray keep your self warme.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Franciscus, and Julio, Julio very poore.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
Forsake me honour, when I doe forget the bond of friendship, let not poverty, no, nor your fathers haviour Julio: though our Venetian law proved him a Traitor: come
plucke away your interest from my breast: when we were pupills in the Academy, I was Franciscus and your fellow then; I am Franciscus and your fellow still, nor can be alte∣red: I have now a heart as free from pride, as when I clipt thee thus, before thou knew'st the taste of poverty, or I pros∣perity. Thinke not ancient friend I can forget thee, though thy need were such as beggery despis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: The liberall hand of heaven reward your love, or lend my wishes that ability to thank you in requitall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Amen to that and more.

I tell thee Iulio, I am not happier in my vertuous wife: and yet that's greater than yielding thee reliefe tis all that good men wish: Why have we wealth bestow'd on us, but to re∣turne the same, where stern necessity pinches the ribs of him or her that wants? it has no other worth, no more esteeme of me. Heap it together while the, massie weight e'ne crack, what bears it lesse than dust? on dust deserves no more re∣gard. I have a Wife, Nurse, and mother, all she is in one; yet one deserves more Titles, besides her feature, which may make compare with those that boast of parts: she is so kinde, that many millions may be stampt againe, ere one so perfect currant. She is worth more than the earth is: but she is my wife, and I will cease her praise: you know her father when you have his name: hee is called Chrisippus, many stile him good, and wish all Venice such.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: Ere I was banish'd for my fathers fact, my know∣ledge coated, and all Italy, spoke of a Damosell called Cor∣nelia, this good Chrisippus daughter.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Chrisippus, Cornelia, Anthonio, Tomaso, Phemono, Stultissimo, and Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: She is that jewell, that unmatched, thing I made my boast of: That Cornelia is none but mine, I dare boldly say, and eke affirme it: See my Julio, she meets us unexpec∣ted, and comes to hinder what I would speake more, in cause of her demerit, modesty, and sweetnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Chris.
SP.P: Franciscus: sonne!

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: My Love and duty make me ever such.
To all this company a happy houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.P: You have bin mist Franciscus.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: You have beene mist Cornelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Where ere I have bin, this is my friend, tender him your welcome with as good respects as I my selfe where he.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.P: Sir, bid your own welcome, and command as much as all we have, were yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio
SP.P: Your courtesies to one so throng'd in misery As my selfe, dulls my behaviour, that I know not how Enough to laud or thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: You shall exchange your habit:
Phemone, sister, Anthonio—

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.P: We mist you yester night.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I durst not come believe it:
Vallentius for sayes rowses are too great,
They make me quake to see 'em.
How fares my cousen Lodwick?

SP.SPEAKER: Anth.
SP.P: He spoyld our sport: he was not well he said:
I would you had beene there: Tomaso pledg'd you twice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I thank his love.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: It is not worth it Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Yfaith Nephew I was extream drunke, aske my man Fub else, he'le tell you what a coyle he had with me: the ra∣rest lest yfaith: prethee tell 'em how thou foundst me under∣neath the staires.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: By no meanes, 'twill make 'em drunk to heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.P: Signior Arbaces you are the man I wisht for.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Well met Gentlemen: are you here Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.P: Cornelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: No, tis no matter. Tomaso you shall do't,
Goe see nothing want; you are all my guests, you dine with
Me that's certaine: Nay, I will not be deny'd:
Most welcome Sir to you: will you walke?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Ever, ever welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Will you walk sir? will you munch?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Sirrah Fub, thou wouldst not think how sore my head is, ever since I had the knock with the Ladle?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: I believe you: will you feed sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: No more i'th' Ladle. Me thinkes I am pocky me∣lancholy here of late.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: So I ghest, ever since you knew the Gentlewoman that beate you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Thou sayest true, ever since yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Why she is able to make any body pocky melan∣choly. But would you would snap a bit sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: I love her I cannot tell how: yfaith and I were well search'd, I think I am little kin to a Spannell, the more I am beaten, the better I affect.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Would I were sure of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Well, she shall heare from me in some Sonnet or Ditty; some rare thing of mine owne invention, and that speedily: Let me see to what tune shall I have it?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
Stultis.
SP.P: By this hand gramercy; they doe indeed, thou canst sing if need be.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: I can make a scurvy shift: But to say truth I am no good Querister.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: But canst thou doe well and scurvily?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: After my manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Would I might be hang'd presently, but methinkes I am a piece of a Poet already, there's such a whistling in my pate.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: That's nothing but your conceit sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Conceit merrily: O that my love were any thing but woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: O that your love were any thing but Common: then might she be.—

SP.SPEAKER: Stu.
SP.P: What might she be.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Nay what you wil yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Stu.
SP.P: Ile to't while tis hot, I know I'me in an excellent vein.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Pricke it quickly then:
But Harke you Signior, shall you not need my helpe?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: I defie't, It shall be all mine own, I cannot abide, tis the scurviest thing to rob others of their wit, good or bad, it shall flow from mine own sweet brain.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: I believe youle finde the tyde turn'd, tis ebbing wa∣ter there, would I might be begg'd, as hee had like to have been, if his foolery do not vex my discretion, but hee gives me means, and I could do little if I could not smile.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Well Vallentius, and you be caught ith' purlues: and you be not stung for't Ile forsweare privacie, and all that belongs too, I have a Girle, the very spirit of what she was made for, and she were honest, she might crave supremacie of Hellen, and make her ride behinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Vallen.
SP.P: And I love one were she not honest, that's her only fault, shee were a Paragon unparalleld, mingle all beautie that our Venice yields, and set her self aside, she would stand peerlesse, over-shine them all, and dimme the Artists cun∣ning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Is she a woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: Yes, but such a one no voluntary habit, nor slie drift with all accommodations that beseemes, unblemisht truth it selfe can bring to speech or give my thoughts ac∣cesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What is she for a Saint, that stands in the how faire and beautifull: may one of my birth intreat her name and knowledge?

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: Vow your assistance to my purposes, and I a Traitour to my selfe reveale the treason of my minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Give me your hand, I am yours for better or worse, in all causes, all adventures, my sword and selfe vow fealty: Is she a wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: I, would she were not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Know you Vanderman our great Physician.

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
Vall.
SP.P: You know hee's married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes, and what of this (oh would you be ministring therein.) I have you my deare Flora, well take my word shee's thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: I would that I were hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Why it lyes in thine own choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: But setting all this pleasantnesse aside, in earnest Lo∣dowick I affect her so, no motive mean nor yet dire accident can change my stedfast will, I must enjoy her, or I must not live.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Thou shalt enjoy her, or I will not live.

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: You speak like a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: I speak like what I am, a Christian, and by that Epe∣thite, I meant as much as I speake, nor could I thinke, Val∣lentius, you of all the men alive, would have mistaken mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: In any kinde but this I never had: pardon me Lodo∣wick this doting loves beares such a jealous sway, the least suspition puts us on the wracke, and breaks all chaines of duty: You may perswade me to believe, but yet he that never saw a Vessell under sayle, cannot imagine what the Seaman brooks, the Merchant sleeping on his downey Cowch, nere dreams what danger the bold Souldier dures, and he that never felt the pangs of Hell, cannot report the torments: assure thee Lodowick so be satisfied, since I knew her, I have not known my selfe, so mighty is loves extreams.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Tis strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: She troth plight was to me, and had been mine, had not desire of pelfe alter'd her friends, and I dare well vow she loved me once, what ere her minde be now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Come be rul'd by mee, thou shalt set thy toe in the Doctors stirrop, ride and go a foot at thy pleasure: did shee love thee once?

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: I had her oath.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
Go to, renew thy suite, the fire is not all out, stir up
the ashes, and thou dost not finde some embers, that will both glow and warme, pawn me for butter'd Sack, and let me ne∣ver be worthy redemption.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I want the means.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Think not of that, tis here my Flora, what man? he's not the first Doctor has worn a corner Cap: come, will you be merry Vallentius, and youle forsake not this mood, I renounce society.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I am yours, obedient as your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Follow me then, and I drive not this melancholly fit out of thee, Ile never trust my conceit: what, ho Dama∣zella? Knocks, and Clarislona looks out at the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Whose there?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: He's here that should be here, come down?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Lodowick.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: What's she.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: The commodity I told you of, there's a Gentleman a friend of yours in love with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Not your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: No faith, though you shall heare her sweare as much, tis our rich heire Signior Stultissimo.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋal.
SP.P: What, the Foole?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: That mor sell of mans flesh, shee cannot beat him a∣way, he haunts the Eves like a Sparrow in March, you may hunt flies from honey sooner then him out of her company: now Mistris how stands things with you, when did you play with your fools bable?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Youle never leave this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Bid my friend welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I thank you Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Come kisse me?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Will you stay all night?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes, when I am weary of strength, and foes with my back.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Yfaith Lodowick, you must leave this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: So I will▪

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: When?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: When thou leav'st thy trade?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Will you sup here?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes drink, nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Lord, how wise your grown?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: So I were, if I could keep out of your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Fie, your'e to uncourteous Lodwick: nay, he's ever thus, but tis my fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Marry mend it then for shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Where's my Bracelet, which of your Truls has that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Shall I be true to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Your'e nere true to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: I mean honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: I care not for your honesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: I believe that too, but in plain verity. Your bracelet embraces my horses main.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Come, you jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: No good troth.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Sweare you, I hope you make a difference between your horse and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Faith but little: and yet your'e both good bearers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋal.
SP.P: By the bright Sun you wrong her: weepe not faire one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What, shall we have tricks?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: You are too blame beshrow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Now, when, what needs all this, nay, and you powt farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: As I am a Gentleman you part not so.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Sweet, Lodwick.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Hum, why was not this before, I have seene the Beares.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Do not I know your woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: Hist, hist, Are you the man of War?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Nay, you must draw neerer, if youle have your Em∣bassie answered: how ist Mistris Durable?

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: How do you Master Lodowick?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: The worse for you, and your creatures.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: It's a good hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Shall I have three or foure words in private?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Not with her unlesse I participate.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: Whats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Yonder's Fub, the parties man you wot on has somthing under hand and seale.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: For me.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: So he gives out.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.P: You may admit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Rest you merry Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Whose this secret party, this conceal'd Champion▪ What have ye here, Signior Stuliissimoes man?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: All haile.

SP.SPEAKER: Vall.
SP.P: This fellow would keep a vilde coyle if hee were a top ath' tiles.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Gentiles, good speed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What, the Plough?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: No, you, and you please, Marona to your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: This fellows discreet.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: To me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: So sayes his backside.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio
SP.P: You the man of War, or more properly Pirat, that gave summons to the leaguer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Leager, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Leager, Sir, the report of your Pot-guns cannot make us hang up a white flag.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.P: The skirt of a clean smock's more proper ath' two.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Wee come not to learne whats proper of you, Monkie, and catch flies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Play at his foolery, come hither Punck.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Sir, y'are uncivill, she's none; nor this a Bawdy house; but a Leaguer of gentle entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: The fellow dreames: Come wake and be thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: My selfe? Would you were as sure your selves as I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: A what?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I'de faine know that of you:
But I advise you to take councell of your best judgment first,
Your words will be questioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodw.
SP.P: Question that dares, th'art an arrant Cheater.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Tis not your pare royall of plush Coxecombes can secure you in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.P: Valiant a the suddaine too.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Not suddainly neither:
The growth has both time and sufficient temper.
Why I a Cheater? let any impartiall—
Ride Circuit, and sit in judgement of us all,
And shew any reason either in Art or Nature,
Why I a Cheater more than any of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Thou hast nothing but a little wit to live upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: That's endowment enough for a Gentleman:
I ever shall count him the nobler gentleman
That makes himselfe a fortune in the world, than he
That brings it into the world with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: Suppose this granted: yet why this a Leaguer?

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: I want words for you: onely for conclusion, one out of a strange affected carriage has gathered an admirable me∣thod of drilling, and training men from the flying of Cranes: Another rare order and government of Common-wealths, from the poore labour of the Bee: And I out of this Leaguer—

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.P: Will extract certaine wayes and carriages for Chea∣ters and Libertines.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.P:
Twere not from my purpose if I granted that to. Ly∣curgus was the first Law-maker; and the best Law that ever he made, was a provision or maintenance for Cheats, as you call em, and Fellons (viz.) That he (without exception of
age, quality, or condition) which could doe the most high dainty, and dangerous peece of Felony, and come cleare off, should be preferred to the most eminent place of office in the State; but if he failed, he was then to receive Martiall Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.P: Strange course, pick Officers out of Fellons.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: 'Tis a kind of Meslin or mingled graine still. How much of the poores money was found in one of the Churchwardens purchase last day?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: None I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: How many theeves horses have bin watered at the High Constable of the hundreds watring trough within this tenne yeares?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: I think not any.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: It may be so: But I am sure, I have heard, or read▪ or something, that a new Chiefe Justice of some place, or a bet∣ter man wo'd not ha made very nice to bid a fat purse to breakfast with him if he light upon it soundly: so that it is not so much the Art to know, as the government to dispose: that quallifies the man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.P: He sayes true: all times ha' bin guilty of good fel∣lowship, why not this? I like the Leaguer now so well, I care not if I buy a place of command in it my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.L: Why now you come to me,
That's the Pearle I ha div'd for all this while:
I have a catalogue of names, places, and prizes.
A cup of entertainment for my friend.
Welcome to the new Leaguer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodo.
SP.L: We'le pledge, we'le pledge:
Victual'd and Win'd already?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
Lod.
SP.P: How now Iulio, gold?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: By this light, and the most curious.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.P:
A poore Grannams gift gentlemen: 300 peeces, or such a taste, parly induction to a businesse, or so. There's a
Burdeaux Merchant in Towne now, would lay me between wind and water this twelve month, but the spite is, I am tyed not to part with this gold for ever: if I knew where to borrow but halfe the worth on't—

SP.SPEAKER: Lodw.
SP.L: Halfe the worth?
Ile vow to lend the full worth,
If that will pleasure thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: You shall keepe the gold under locke and key for your pawne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Thou shalt not want for such a courtesie to doe thee good: Ime glad th'art so thriving.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: Lock up the boxe, and keep the key; there's the full summe.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: To a Piece I assure you: you shall see else agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: No more, no more trouble:
Let me see for how long?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Three Moneths, not a day longer:
Nay sooner if mony chance to come in afore:
I have offices in my Leaguer stand upon Fortunes hill.
'Vds me Signior Stultissimo promied
Me a courtesie last night:

SP.SPEAKER: Monkey.
SP.P: Assure thee sweet chuck he'le not faile thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: I believe thee without an oath:
Make my friend welcome to the Leaguer Monkey:
As soone as I have dispatch'd my voyage
To the Canaries, I am for you agen Lads.

SP.SPEAKER: Whor.
SP.P: Gentlemen, who can read?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Who cannot?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: I can resolve you:
She cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What's here?
Opprobrious Saint, and most Angellicke fiend,
Ere I begin, thus doe I make an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I should have beene sorry else:
Nay silence, or the Proclamation's lost.
And if thy heart be not patcht up in Marble,
Harke how my pen does in thy prayses warble.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: O deare Apollo, how art thou abus'd, Is there more?

LG.L: Sweet stinging Waspe, and well conceited Dove▪
For beauty nice, intituled Queen of love
Of me; Sir reverence; that doe's thee adore;
Which art esteem'd a good one and no more:
Let reason rule thy Amazonian sist▪
Let ladle rude be thrown at hady wist,
So shall I love thee, take it for no fable
Better then well, and more then I am able.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Yours despite your guts. S. S.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Asse, Asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: The Authours name.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Cannot you get her Signior Stultissimo?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: O, lamentable complaint!

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: As ever poore man heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Will he take no warning.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Is this a Challenge?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Fie no, they are too violent to come in rime.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Lodowick, is not this your practice?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Why, dost thou think me so simple, so ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: No, Ile assure you, It's a token of good will of my Masters, there's no brain guilty ont but his own: if you like it you may, and you will not, the laws in your own hands, you may choose.

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Good Gentlemen return the Carrier.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What? a cuffe or a knock.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Hee has penn'd a Song too, which I should have tickled, if I had not been hoarse with drinking Flap-Dra∣gons last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Whats thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Prethee honest Fub, tickle thy selfe out of our com∣panies, weele be Fubb'd no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Will not you be Fubb'd Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Thou knowest my resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Nay, but will ye not indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: No faith▪

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: I am glad I know't,—be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Have you any wine ith' house?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: Yes dearest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Come, a pox a these devices, hang off: will you drink Vallentius?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Will I live?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Where's the Matron?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: The Matron, Lord, you're the strangest man.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Your Matron Grandum, what will you have it, your Bawd?

SP.SPEAKER: Whore.
SP.P: I must be quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋal.
SP.P: Nay, enter, enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: The easie time, and such as thrive in it, favour my wishes, the ignorant whose sole dependance is on veritie, and carry conscience in their timorous brests, are not asso∣ciates meet for Iulio. Those that neere knew the straine of Policie, nor ayme at more, then what may well content, draw not my length, the way to prosper, the directest course such are my sore necessities, is to get liking of this lovely Maid Franciscus sister, bright Phemone, the Virgin's mo∣dest, chast, and debonaire, besides her brother's rich, there hang my hopes, but shee affects not mee, all her desires are on young Anthonios, rich Arbaces sonne, my friend (suppos'd) at least, but that is breath; by what man has, or can have, he's my foe that hinders my designe, where hee my next of bloud, that shall he finde: the meane to purchase what I reach at now, there is but only one, one only meane that can supplant him, here it lies shall doo't, were hee as deare in estimation as Nisus to Eurialus.
SP.L: I love my selfe, I count him still most wise,
That cares not who's thrown down so he arise.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus secundus. Scena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Franciscus and Julio. sound Musick.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: THou hast to say somthing, yet nothing I hope triviall, by our known affection I beseech thee, speak what thou canst.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I would I had embraced my povertie, while the pale Moone has residence in heaven, would I had beene deafe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Whereto tends this speech if I thought my fault, or any ones pertain'd to mee, through wilfull negligence, or otherwise, to breed the occasion of this passionate mood, I should condemne the cause of the offence, and deeme my self unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Can heaven suffer it?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran,
SP.P: What, what does heaven suffer, speak my Iulio?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Too much of ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Let me know that ill, and I rest satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Pray no more, the malady is mortall, unsanctified, monstrous. Anthonio is there such a man?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Many that weare that name in Italy: but one a∣mongst that many known to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Hate all the name.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Pardon Iulio, Ile hate my selfe first.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: Anthonio is a Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran,
SP.P:
Blot not the reputation of his youth with such
calumnie, he is no way such, but as unblemisht, as the snow before it touch the Mountains.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: He's a Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Villain never had so faire an out-side, nor yet heart so just as that he carries.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: He's a Villain.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I have some businesse at the Port, youle sup with me to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Doe you love your selfe, do you love honour, do you love your wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Then hate that Anthonio.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Give me to understand, since you will force me to endure your report, wherein hee's culpable, or does deserve these ignominious titles.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: He loves not you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Tis not my fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: He wrongs your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Therein, he's too blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: He loves your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: That amends, quits all his former wrongs.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Can you beare it thus, wink Vulcan then,
And let the god of Warre, throw up her skirts agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: You will not understand; Ile speak no further.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Come, come, my wife is honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: If she be, tis nothing you have said, Ile heare no more; begon.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: Will you list a word, Anthonio wongs you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Wrong me, and if he would he cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: He playes the Parasite, the officious Asse to vaile his sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Would I might understand you?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: The Serpent tempts your wife, these eares and eyes can testifie; for your sister, she's stale: his excuse, whereby hee cloakes his vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I wish you Iulio, to know what you speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I am not mad, I love you, tis my love, you are my fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I pray be advised, consider what you do? speak not this no report, be certain; do not abuse my patience. Tempt my wife, rent earth, and swallow falshood.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Will you be moved Pernassus, the two topt, forked Mount?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: My bloud is not mine own, I want command of all that now obeyed me, how different are my fits? I am now a congealed, kneaded cake of ice, bound from all motion, now again (mee thinks) a flaming Iland, a Vesunius Hill, meerly combustion.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Forget not, sir, your patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Tell me of patience when I am my selfe: how did he tempt her, how did she accord on thy reputation?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I would I had been dumbe?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Hang not ith' winde, (delay does torture) answer me as how?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Kinde, sir, recall your wonted manhood?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Answer me how.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I pray pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: What? strike and cry mercie, I must be resolved, thou hast flung me ith' fire, even in the Oven, the mouth of Aetna, nothing thou coulst have said, nothing have done, could have assured like torture.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Would, when I saw him kisse her, crush her hand, wink and laugh out, use his undecent language: Fie, fie.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Cornelia false, the floud may come agen, nothing impossible, kisse, and crush hands, wink, wink heaven and all above.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Kind, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Beare witnesse, all that good are, how deare, how deare, I held that most false man: set him here, here, even on the spire and pinacle of my heart; my life was his, and all that I call mine, but her he has abused?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P:
Deare friend, do not forget your name, these are but likelihoods, farre from the thing it selfe, and say he be a Vil∣laine,
as no doubt he's little better in his rude exposures: she may be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: No Julio, no, had she meant well,
She would have warnd me of his foule attempts,
Said such, and so's his haviour.
When she was loyall, as sure one shee was,
(If ever any was) no accident how vaine
So e're it seemed, but she a woman, would unfold
Her sexe, and say 'twas thus, and thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I have stroke him through.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Treble abuse:
Deflowred my wife, abused me,
Disgraced my sister; throwne infamy
On all our heads at once: What beast uncivill bred,
Amongst carelesse Monsters (but thee Antonio)
Would have beene kickt on to that damned enterprise?
That I had patience; me thinks thou shouldst not
Be the Villaine yet, report does speake thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Nay gentle friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Tis true, 'tis true.
Had any 'twixt the North and Southerne Pole
Spoke these words but hee, it had not beene,
And he had falsely lyed.
This is a Creature I have rais'd, reviv'd,
Snatch'd from destructions teeth,
Incorporated to me, so deare and just, as not
A thing in all the world can be more truer to it selfe
And certaine: but his modesty conceales it,
Could write a Volume of their loath'd designes,
And curse the stories cause. O false Cornelia!

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.L: Remember what you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Remembrance burst!
There's no contemplation, nothing what ere can
Drive the thought of shame out of my mind:
Would I had never knowne discretion,
Could never have made distinctions of persons,
And harmlesse Creatures; hence forth be ignorance:
Mother of Nations and Vnderstanding perish:
Faire, foule Cornelia. The blue fac'd
Occan, nor her fertile wombe, that yields
Vs all increase, nourishes none so false as woman:
Traytors have they been since their first being,
And betray'd poore man e're he beheld himselfe.
Cornelia can it be thou art a Strumpet?
Oh, oh, fury finish that, burnes thee to Cynders.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Worke on, worke on:
Fate lifts me to the seat of my desires;
And I am prosperous and happy.
This Devill jealousie, my present friend,
Cannot at least but quite supplant Anthonio:
Besides this seeming honesty of mine, begets me good
Opinion of Franscicus, as shall install my wish;
All addes to my availe: what need I curses feare
For the debate my policy shall raise betwixt these Turtles▪
I hold with Machievel, for fame or profit
To breake oath or league with friend,
Or Brother: there's nothing gainfull bad:
I ha my wish, Advancement now
Is what I aime at, present glory here:
He's true religious, that does nothing feare.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Thomaso, Valentius, Lodwicks, Stultissimo, and Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: And how? and how?
Was it not patheticall and pretty?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Y faith I never heard the like.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: I thanke the Muses, I have as sharpe a conceite of mine owne when I list.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Sir I take you to be a great devourer of Verjuyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Now and then; but 'tis not altogether that; every one has his gift.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Tis so.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: Some has two or three.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: You say true Signior, some has twenty: for which they may thanke impudency and the art of begging.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: The art of begging: pray you how long has begging beene an art?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Ever since in rid in a foote-cloath, and wore the badge of authority.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: How long's that agoe?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Ever since you Grannams daughter had a Calfe of your age.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes, and will continue till hee's a Bull and horne mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: Most miraculous: would I were mercinary, and had no more in me than an ordinary man: Signior, I crye you mercy. How doe you since you powred the pottle of wine in my neck, and threw the pot at my head, because I would not pay my part o'th shot?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: Was there such a time?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Was there? Why have you forgot how you kickt me, and I crept under the Table: Ile be sworne this Hip's as lame ever since, as if I had the Cyatica.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Absurd and grosse.

SP.SPEAKER: Vallen.
SP.P: We must leave you Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: I thanke you with all my heart: I am going to the foresaid place: here's my servant Fub can tell you if I lye in my throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: I will assure you he's wandring to Pusse, or as a man would say, to deale with Mistris Clariflora.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: Yes faith am I: she beat me tother day, and I am now going to make her amends. I thinke I endure more beating than any three in Venice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Than a Stock-fish.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: 'Tis a signe you are offensive.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: So they say that do't. Yester night a scurvy boy did so joule my head and the wall together, for holding o∣pinion that Cheese was unwholsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: No more good Signior: farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: At your service:
Shall we expect you at the old house?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: If you please:
Have you heard the like?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: These are Asses so tedious—

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: They're kin to Burs, they will not off with shaking.
Now my Thomaso what I have to say:
The chiefe occasion made me summon you,
Is to entreate your knowledge and assistance
In such a project, (as your selfe set by) and him that must
Partake in the attempt, Venice in Italy
Conceales the man that I durst credit.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Let it not touch confusion of the State,
Treason, and Murther: whatsoe're it be,
Command my will and sufferance.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Defend that ever I should be such:
Vallentius never had so foule a thought,
To infect himselfe, and others.
Thus, in briefe, I love a woman; fairer
Than her selfe ne're wore the Epethite:
You have seene her sure, and know her:
She's wife to Vanderman.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Correma's daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: That same onely wight, is the most precious
Beauty I adore, and would faine call mine own.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Knew you her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: By his name, no further;
By that knowledge you understand his course.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Yes he's a Physitian: and besides,
What else report speaks of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Listen then my purpose,
The severe sir, whose high stretcht phrases
Galls the eares of Patience, and wisedom would fain shun,
Beares such a jealous and observant eye
Over the prey I aime at, all conference is debar'd,
And you may sooner whisper with the Saint
Argos had charge of, than converse with her,
Vnseene, and unsuspected.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Is there no device to compasse her?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: But one, and this is it;
Your selfe and Lodwicke (harken I beseech you)
Shall to this skilfull Vanderman present me
As one distracted: nay smile anon,
And with a kinde of sober modesty, as if you list you can,
Report some probable possibility, how
And which way I got my extasie:
Let me alone to make your words seeme truth,
And so possesse my prating Mountebanke,
That he shall say and sweare I'me mad at least.
If not past all recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Will this doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: This, or none.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Then none.
Why this is the shallowest, indirectest course to win a wo∣man that ever was compos'd, in my opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: In your opinion: why sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: Why, hope you to gaine her thus with a mad fit: marke the event, this is a course as wide: Are you so simple to imagine, she a timerous woman, will endure your pre∣sence, seeming possest? for shame believe it not, invent some other meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodw.
SP.L: I verily thinke so too, but he will never bee per∣swaded.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: This were a way to scare her, and to make her shun you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodw.
SP.L: Leav't off, leav't off, and study some other new passage.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Doe, doe; this is the grossest: fie Vallentius:

SP.SPEAKER: Lodw.
SP.L: Come, you shall pardon him once: wee all misse sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P:
Good gallants doe not ride me, lest I gall you: Ile assure you I trot hard: why my brace of conceits, my wits; what does your abundance of wit runne at waste: for shame, have you so poore a braine, and you my most exquisite ex∣cellent,
for shame take off your spectacles and see better: are you such a dunce: are you so rare a Coxcombe, to deeme I will appeare alwaies the same: are you the men you promist? will you be Masters of your words and oaths, tender your vow'd assistances?

SP.SPEAKER: Lodw.
SP.L: I am Lodwicke still.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: And I Tomaso.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Continue so: what shall redound upon this adven∣ture, falls upon my head, be it no shame to yours: onely pre∣ferment and your smooth apologies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Leave that to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: But can you act the mad-man bravely?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Tut, I have play'd Ajax, and perform'd the part wel, to make boast of imitation, better than he that Lucian writes of, who so digested what he plaid, that he run mad indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Can you do't?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: So well, as Aesop could discharge his Scene, where∣by he won most laud.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: This praise were well in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Mistrust not my behaviour, and if it prove not cor∣respondent to my word, thinke me an idle vanter, and no meet associate for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: When put we this in practice?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: There's no deferring weekes, nor dayes, this houre, this very evening does my fit begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Shall we about it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: What else, what else? Remember gentlemen you fall not upon the scandall of Ignorance: but in any case keep your countenances.

SP.SPEAKER: Lodw.
SP.L: Make no doubt of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Come then, and fortune friend us.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Francisco, and Antonio, as in a Grove.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Draw your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Gainst whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: 'Gainst me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Gainst any living man thats your enemy:
What ailes my deare Francisco?
By your face you should not be in health.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Draw your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: What meane you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Draw your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: 'Gainst you never in anger:
Are you well Franciscus? me thinkes your cheeke
Carries a paler hue than wont to be his Livery.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I must fight with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: With me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: With thee perfideous monster, with thee thou Iudas.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Are you your selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Thou hast abused me, wronged me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I wrong'd and abus'd you?
Franciscus, can you think so of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Doe not enquire; yonder he sits knowes all:
Look yonder, thou art to him transparent, and seen through,
As easie as the aire: doe not cloak thy vice, doe not:
See'st thou this? see'st thou the place we tread on?
Marke my speech, one of us twaine, or both (never start)
On this cold earth, this very Champion, shall
Offer up a crimson sacrifice of his most precious blood:
For that cause drew I to this silent shade,
Remote from all suspition, where
Revenge might glut with satisfaction:
Draw thy sword, or else thou never shalt.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Did not my love prohibit,
Thinke, Francisco, I could not be a Coward,
Nor endure the opprobrious taunts the malice
Of your heart has made your tongue throw on me;
Why I know not: believe me, and receive it for a truth,
Were you some other, in this wide vast world,
And not Franciscus, you had beene a dogge
That I had kickt long since; but you are my friend,
And my disgrace is buried: yet if you carry honour
In your breast, and beare your wonted venerable mind,
Make me to understand from whence, or why your
Comminations & undecent language point thus at me alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Will you draw?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Do you thirst for bloud? if so, and mine, hide to the hilts your naked instrument, my bosome is your mark: thrust home and take your fill.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Will you draw?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You had mine answer, never▪ never.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Do you not love my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes, by Heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Confesse, ô impudence! my wrong cryes out, no more expostulation, remember Iulio.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Wherefore him, he is a Toad more virulent, oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Bathe there, adulterate fiend, and thy red drops wash off thy guilty stains.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Oh, some charitable creaure!
Francisco, dear Francisco.
No pittie, no remorse, I bleed, and much effusion robs me of my breath, something of sence relieve me, help, ô help.

SP.SPEAKER: Shep.
SP.P: That dying tune, was sure a mans, where art thou friend, speak thou that cryd'st for help, if thou wouldst have thy wish, speak once again: where art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Here.

SP.SPEAKER: Shep.
SP.L: To one in thy case could I nere lesse wish, then health and mercy, how fare you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Oh! Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Shep.
SP.P: His utterance is decayed, and life begins to creep out of his wounds: let me see, so many, and so mortall! can I but stay the course I wish no more: have I nothing left, to stay this passage: well, yet still hee breathes, that I had here some help. Thy aid Omnipotent, yet his pulses beat, life is not quite discharged,—no succour! keep he but mo∣tion, till I can beare him to my Cell, I doubt not, his re∣covery: this winde, this winde, that my Balmes were here: for my youthfull dayes heaven lend ability.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Crissippus, Tomaso, Lod wick, Iulio, Cornelia, and Phemone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Run to all brief confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Good, sir, be pacified.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.P: Even in the pride, and noon time of his fortunes, brought to destruction thus: a milder, better tempered Gen∣tleman, Venice nor Europe yielded; his knowledge made me proude, and I was rich in his adoption.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: O my Franciscus, ô my gentle Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: My brother, my deare brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.P: My sonne, my sonne, so noble, valiant, wise, dearer to me then him I call mine owne by true succession, doe you weep?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I am not blest, all things doe sort contrary; 'twill not do, my projects thrive not, would I had been silent, wee know the first, but not the last, I begin to perceive our poli∣cies of times whets the Axe, cuts off our own necks; I have and one my selfe, that it should come to this, wee seeke to mend so long, that we marre all: for mine own part, would I could have been content: but who would have dreamt the course would have proved so violent: well this I am sure on, I may starve ere I get such another friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.P: Sister, if it be true, as so the rumour goes, you have playd false, and wronged your dearest friend: you are not worthy such another man, you sole Queene of Africk; had you to live as many ample yeares as our first fathers, or their ages thrice: you might spend all those tedious houses twice told, ere you finde a Mate so worthy, were you equivalent, in birth and beauty, and had no paralell: Neptunes gems to boot, you want worth and excellencie both, to weigh down his demerit; Vertue and Honour stampt him for their own, at his first being, and the Graces strove to increase his pleni∣tude. More perfection then he has, hee needs not, where ere he's betook.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Somthing that's mighty, stain me Leopard like, if ere I gave offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: I should be loath to wish so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Not you offend? look here,
This letter left he as a testimony,
Who is there here 'mongst all this company,
That knew Franciscus, knew not he affected,
And highly priz'd the slain Antonio?
What could have rais'd such deadly enmity?
But this, but this, thou strumpet,
Between such twinlike friends?
Thy misdemeanour, thy approved falsnesse;
Which too, too well he knew▪
Thou hast und one him,
Fled he is and gone;
His goods already seiz'd are for the State:
And die he shall if ever he be took,
Oh, fie upon thee my perpetuall shame!

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Can you this behold, you upright Justices?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Thou art not mine, I here deny thy claime,
And warn thee hence-forth,
Come not neere my roofe:
Pine, starve and die, reliefe and comfort
Never more expect from him that was thy father.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: 'Tis nothing I see, to work the dissolution of a house,
How easily this is done?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: I must weep, to deeme
I should be forc'd to be so cruell;
More I have to say, if teares would let me;
(Me thinks) I could both kisse and curse her:
If she be wrong'd, and through some make-strife,
These foule ills prove a greater plague,
Then fell in Egypt, light on the Authors head,
The maws of Dogs be his Tombe:
Help me to curse him Iulio.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Ten thousand swords strook me together.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Liv'd there such a wretch,
And that I knew him,
Let my faith not save me,
But I would teare the Viper with my teeth,
And like a rude and savage Caniball,
Eate out his treacherous heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Now the foule Devill, stuffe thy glutnous paunch,
I am no viand for thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Who's this comes here, Arbaces?

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Arbaces, with two or three Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Disgrace and woe smite all this company, and make them feele my griefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Disgrace, contagion, and what can be worse,
Smite thee and all thy tribe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Undone, undone, where is Anthonio?
Where's my sonne Crisippus?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Answer thine own words;
Where's mine Arbaces?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Where such a Villain—
And fell murtherer should.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: More charity for shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Sorrow gripe my heart till it be bloud lesse,
But what thou speak'st is false:
A more slanderous lye never left the lips of any.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Lye?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.L: Sir, be perswaded.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Tell not me, Ile prove it on him, Arbaces, boy—

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: That we were alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Well said, old Lad.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Shew thy self a man, meet me to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Good, sir, forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Not meet him.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.L: Will you be entreated?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Give me leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Will you be pacified?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Meet thee, yes I will meet thee;
I dare meet a man: Arbaces thou shalt finde it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Come, you are a prater.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Prate; ye shall heare from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: With reverence of your age, good sir,
You want of that discretion and stayd judgement;
Your yeares and place requires: It is not well,
One of your reputation and report,
Should so forget your self: to be plain,
You lack advice; and this same cavillation,
Meerly provok'd by you.
Proclaymes a loud your inconsiderate folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Sir, sir; check your own:—
You never lost a sonne, and cannot
Ayme at my affections and paternall care:
You have undone me—
Robb'd me of my joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: You are not right considerate,
Who has undone you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: You, you, and shee, and every one of you;
The punishment for murder fall on all your heads,
And blast your terrene hopes:
Cruell, cruell, butchery.
Wast not sufficient that he took his life,
As by his own confession:
Undid his wofull mother and my self,
But he must practice more
Immanly, more dire austerity;
Throwing his breathlesse trunk
In some obscure night-shaded Mansion,
A prey for ravenous beasts;
Where never eye of creature rationall,
Shall more behold him: unchristian part,
If there be justice, above or here;
As certainly there's both: Ile petition,
My lowd complaints shall pierce both sides o'the globe,
And strike a sorrow in the rudest thing,
Nature for mans use moulded:
O! my Antonio? my joy, my life;
My deare, my deare Antonio.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: There's cause for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Sure, sure, how fond was I
That could not weigh this before;
Having his proper cause,
If for some not slaughtred,
Nor mine own, but by selection,
I could sigh my age, shed flouds of teares,
Meet dangers in my shirt, bid conquering
Death defiance, if all this and more I durst attempt,
For one no otherwise, then mine by law;
Needs must he rave past rules of Manhood,
And forget all precepts that support his suffrance:
See you this? What think you of your self?
Have you not done well? account thou scandall,
That like the Whore of Greece,
Was teem'd for mans destruction;
Thy sin upon thy self, my doore is shut;
That hospitality I shew a stranger,
Shall be restrained from thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Most courteous sir,—expect more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Keep your Orisons to charm relenting beggers.
Such in need, as may thy wants relieve;
Or at least sympathy thy mournfull tale,
When fierce distresse smiles,
Expect more comfort from the blustring North,
When he does blow the highest Acorn head
Down to the Medow, and there dips his cup;
Then least relief from me, for thee;
For thee chast Maid, all benisons,
And goodnesse, that I can, command and have.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Your liberality was ever such,
As merits more then thanks; yet thus far,
Truth emboldens me to say you are too cruell kinde,
Not all the proofs,
What ere incenst my brother to his rage;
Can wean me to that vain opinion,
To think it her desert: I dare protest for her,
No perswasion can drive belief in me,
To call Antonio false; if you prove so cruell,
So unnaturall as you speak, there is no pitty in you:
Nor are you such as a father ought to be,
Thrust her out, then turn me off;
If you supplant one, you extirp us both,
And her extreams are mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Since you disdain my proffer'd courtesie,
Together shelter your necessities;
Take up your habour with the hardy beast;
These gates are lockt to her and her relievers
Hence-forth I will forget her,
Blot her name forth of the Bed roule
Where my children stand,
And vow I had none such:
Hence, hence, thou scandall.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.L: Thus guilt lesse ones, suffer the guilties blame,
While they triumph in fraude, thus the strict Judge
Condemnes th'innocent for the thieves offence;
Whilst partiality allows his wrong,
And greatnesse makes it good;
Will equity never take place again?
Has trust left swaying here? that I but knew my crime:
Or that Francisco but beheld my heart!
Let mine eyes rain a river of salt drops,
And my tears drown me, if any foule sin of mine,
Deserve Franciscoes hate:
I had rather heaven had made me any thing,
Then one so much unhappy,
When ere thou bidest on the plenteous shore,
Or labouring floud,
Prosperity adhere to thy proceedings,
And fame conclude thy deeds,
For me despised, such be my fortune as my loyalty,
And I request no more,
My sweet, my sweet Francisco.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Heaven do thee right.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: And if thou beest not honest,
There's neither pride nor coozenage in this Citie:
If every conscience were well searcht,
And you did not finde
Some dainty fine conceited Rogue
Has been tempering,
Let me return to my Cradle,
And be hang'd in my swadling clouts.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus tertius. Scena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Vallentius, and Doctors Wife, Lodowick, Tomaso, and Julio.

SP.SPEAKER: Tomaso.
SP.P: THink you it so?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Yes, and verily believe't.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.P: Tis strangly carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Mark the end, marke the end;
Why do you sigh, Signior?
Are you troubled with the Crampe?

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: O, blame him not, he has good cause to sigh,
Francisco set by him precious: How fare you, Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Never worse, my Friend's undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
I, a mischiefe and a vengeance oth' cause, by this sword, nay, feare not man, I am not angry, and I could not judge, well, I say no more: but if hee did not walke on
Stilts, I do detest eating and drinking, and those are two ne∣cessaries, a man can hardly live well without them.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: The very Paragon, mirrour of the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: If I could not have wept when I beheld her, and that was more then I did at the death of my father, I have no be∣liefe in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Who but she, the wonder of our age.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: No more words, mark the end, marke the end; I say, still mark the end.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: I must leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Not as the wench left the Frenchman in the suds, there's neither mettle nor society in thee; if thou abando∣n'st my company, till we have visited Valentius.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: I wonder how he speeds?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Did he not act the madman to the life, was't not wel? could ever a Dunsticall Doctor in this Towne, have pickt falshood out of his behaviour: he was so mutable, so full of varying tricks (me thinks) I see him yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.P: Defer your visitation till to morrow, or late some∣time to night: I am yet unfit, this sudden trouble has made me not my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nay, you must goe; I have sworne you shall, and (that presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: I pray you pardon me,

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I will not be deny'd, refuse me now and ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Youle have your humour still?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What, eschew acquaintanceship? forget, After my most hearty commendations, my very trusty friend, 'Twere sin and shame Tomaso.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: But some other time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: This time, sometime, other times, and all times, this day, yesterstay, tother day, and every day; no houre amisse, march on, march on.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P:
I could launch my Dagger through my side, at one easie throw: begger my friend; subvert mine owne estate, and undo her, by whom I hope to climbe, accursed, brainles slave: could the damn'd Devill with all his fire-brands, beat into my pate no sounder subtilty. I had, I had reliefe, Foole
vaunt of that?▪ boast what thou hadst? or might have? tis past, 'tis gone, my villaine selfe, confounded has my selfe, and him that did sustaine me:
SP.L: What choaks Corne sooner than side-fed weeds,
Who ofter does man wrong than he afeeds:
Let me ponder; have I no other invention?
No trick to take away my life, after my meanes:
Study upon't, I'me strooke upon a sand,
Swallow'd, devowr'd, through wilfull ignorance,
Never to rise againe: 'tis a villaines cast,
First to sinke others, them himselfe at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: You cannot blame me neither:
For love himselfe undertooke more for love;
Had you been tangled in a Labyrinth more intricate
Than held the Minataure, or have beene
By Inchantments bound to servitude,
My life's adventure had my love exprest,
And offered the release.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct. wife.
SP.L: Our plighted amities will dwell in me
While life endures; the many winters, & the tedious hours
We two have spent alone, alone Vallentius,
When nothing but what was not fit the Sunne
Should look upon,—Alacke my Husband.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Doctor, Thomaso, Lod wicke, Stultissimo, and Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: It must not be denyed, Ile maintaine't before the Synod, here's my witnesse: was't not well done of brave Caligula to make his horse a Senator? deny't, deny't, would not a good horse shew well among a teame of Asses: ha, what thinke you: give me another sword: O noble Hector, looke, Achilles flyes, and bloody Pyrrhus shrinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Alas, alas.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: What newes, what newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: Gentlemen he takes me for a Carrier:
You are deceived sir, I am not the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Will Pluto keep his word, shall all extortioners, en∣grocers, usurers, be finely damn'd, of what kind soe're? will he spare none?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Wondrously spent.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Let me see, let me see, the sonne of Panace, a sprightly Lad; Hercules, a lusty youth, a very lusty youth; Sampson, a tall young man, a very tall young man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Does he not do't well?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Ile make thee proov't, Ile make thee proov't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: I thinke you are mad:
What shall I prove?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Why greatest generalls, that command whole Legi∣ons, and traine, and keepe in order every man, cannot keepe in a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: That's an easie question, because most of them get Follies wings, and grow so light there's no ho with them: they must flye out.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Hang them, they are naught all: Tell not me learned Ovidius Naso, what's your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: That bloody villaine: Treason gentlemen, call up a Guard, the traytor's discovered: binde him sure, sure: are you tooke napping sirrah: Downe with him, downe with him, downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Helpe, helpe, helpe Gentlemen.

DIV1.STAGE: Vallentius beates him in, the gentlemen would come between. Exit all but the Doctors wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: I doe not like this.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Valentius againe, and kisses her.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Now my sweet I have sent him off in post,
Let us retire the while.
Who in affection will not his wits prove,
Was never loyall, nor did ever love.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P:
Past, past cure, I doubt. Give me leave, I finde by
my Art 'tis no Vertiga, no whirling, but a meere setled frenzy: Nay I pray you give me leave: for as both Hypocra∣tes, and Gallen, Avicen, Podalirius, Rucis, Cornelius, Celsus, Corannus, Augustino, and Rombart, doe you conceive mee? besides a dozen or two of English-men, most learned and worthy physitians (if I knew what they were) have demon∣strated paraphrastically, both it and the cause, styling the malady the digestion of the braine, or Irrevocabilis ignis, the irrevocable fire: Nay, will you understand me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Would we could.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: I pray you give me leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Who hinders him?

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: Sir if you can speake our tongue, I would very faine be beholding to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Art thou mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: Not altogether mad, though I confesse I have beene prickt with the thornes of Love: I have beene over shooes in my dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Avoydance, for charity avoydance.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: Yes marry shall you: I would desire you to helpe me to a pill, or a potion that could make one honest, that I doubt is a little gone astray.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Avaunt, avaunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: No sir, she is none of my naunts: shee's one that must be my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Turbulant fiend: avaunt, avaunt I charge thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: I would have it applyed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Illiterate dunce, abandon my house, avaunt I say againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.P: Nay, I pray you be quiet, for though I have endu∣red many hard words at your hands, I shall hardly brooke blowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Good gentlemen give me leave to laugh: ha, ha, ha, the Doctors wife, and the Mad-man: the mad-man, and the Doctors wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Why, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Why sir, the fits upon him, and he's upon her, and younder's such sport, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Fire and Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Runne: ware hornes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Is this true sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Follow the Doctor, believe your eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Beware the trap Valentius.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Pray heaven he be not tane with nibbing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Why are you melancholy Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: Faith sir I' me troubled with cornes, and ever against raine they make me so melancholy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Is that it, for the thing you spake on, you shall not be beholding to the scald peremptory Doctor: Come to my Chamber anon, and Ile give you a powder shall fulfill your request, as well as all the potions or Pills he can devise.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Nay, but will you be constant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Say no more:

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: And you doe take my word, while I live: She and I will be at your service: when shall I come for't?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod
SP.L: Any time after noone. Will you walk Tomaso?

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: This is good newes withall my heart: Fub we are all made; thou shalt have a new Livery out of the bargaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: I thanke you sir, I would I had it.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: Thou shalt, thats as good: would I were whipt but I could be monstrous merry now.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: No I pray you bee not monstrous merry till you are married.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: Ile goe give thee a pottle of Sack.

LG.HEAD: The Taverne Sceane.
LG.L: And ever he gave her a bob,
And ever he gave her a blow:
But where he knockt her once above,
He thumpt her thrice below.

SP.L: What wil't not doe? prethee-let's be lusty.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: As a Crow in a Gutter. Run there she goes.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Antonio, and the old shepheard disguised.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Father, for so I must stile you,
Your care and paines in my recovery,
Deserves a recompence more than I am able to performe:
Now I consider with my selfe, had we compassionate soules,
Or were men but good, they would banish beggery
The World quite over, and every one have sufficient.
As hitherto you have conceald my course,
Continue still your wonted secresie,
Call me your sonne, and such appoyntments as a father
Should command me to endure I shall performe:
Blessed, blessed be you: effectuall be my prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Shep.
SP.L: The longer time you so journe here with me
The more welcome: nothing more I crave;
But if I dye while you recide i'th' grove,
Out of your charity you'le take the paines
To lay me in the grave I have prepar'd, and with your hand,
Your foote, or any thing, cast dust upon my body,
And spend a little Ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: More than this I will, and more than I will speak.
Francisco, whersoe're thou bidest, abide in quiet,
And have my pardon ever. If thou be'st fled
For any cause of mine, and I thy ruine prove,
Defend it heaveu, were't not for triall of Phemone's love,
And promis'd constancy, how soone would I renounce
My habitatiation, uncloath thy feare, & set all even againe?
Nothing 'mazes, nor drives me into that serious
Contemplation, as whence his wrath should proceed.
Perchance Franciscus thinkes me unfit to call him brother,
And his sud daine rage proceeded from advice.
If it be so for ever will I keep this shady bower,
And never hold companionship with man,
More than is present, forget Arbaces ever
Cal'd me his, or that I was his sonne.
Circle me safety, what are these come here
Where never neighbourd welt?

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Calamity could not inflict so much as I could beare
With patienee, did Franciscus imagine but the truth:
No lenity, but all extreames that may
Attend me with their sharpest violence,
If e're I broke my vow: this sorrow,
Nor the haviour I sustaine are for mine owne endurings,
Witnesse you that know all secrets, 'tis for him
I wish thrice better than my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Yes, and that Cornelia; as sure as the black Ousell
Has a yellow mouth, that whistles me awake.
Tis she, or I am fond.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: O my Franciscus! O my dearest Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: There needs no more for confirmation:
What make they here? Doe not undoe me wonder.
Ne're had two ragged coats more orient pearles,
Than you two shells doe hide: 'tis she, or I am fond,
Leap not forth with joy, such needy robes
Should wrap the shoulders of necessity,
When winter falls the Leafe: happy Antonio,
I am disguised, and so, if that my speech reveale not,
Without suspect I may obtaine my wish,
And have all doubts resolv'd: Ile greet 'em.
Bonny wight, what e're you be,
Lucke be in your company:
Are you Sylvanus, say to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Phem.
SP.L: None such, good Shepheard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Deft and trim ones mickle glee,
Be you what you please to be,
Some disaster tend by yee,

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Never, never more.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: A me unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Welladay, now by my Creed,
And my merry Oaten Reed,
Sike another rousing sigh
Would well split me gay and blith:
Let a loutish Clowne partake,
Why this sobbing dole you make?

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: O inconstant world.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: A me unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Wonderment of woe relate
If simplenesse you might not scorne,
How you hapt to be forlorne.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: The story would be too tedious for the time,
And would undoe the speaker: Friend no more,
You shall doe well to leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Be not all too keene, bright starre,
If my pertnesse went too farre,
Mercy is the doome I sue,
Good things never meant more true,
Than the silly shepheard did,
Late wen he your sorrow bid:
Discourse the meanes merry Pan,
And the sagest gods doe scan;
Wherefore was it? well a neare,
You foule mucky cloud I feare
Will be sprint us, Poebus twaine,
If so list you but to daine
A poore shepheards entertaine,
Welcome should you be, I wisse,
Nor thing comely should you misse,
Though not courtly: answer make,
Will you my small feasting take?

SP.SPEAKER: Phem.
SP.L: The raine begins to fall;
Sister accept the Shepheards courtesie,
His simplenesse cannot but meane well sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Corn.
SP.L: Even what you please:
Whither I goe, or wheresoe're I rest,
Sorrow with me, and I with sorrow feast.
Welcome, welcome, welcome still,
Never with a freer will
Was welcome spoken, by the skie;
Welcome, welcome heartily.
Alacke, alacke, the rotten south
'Gins to ope his dewy mouth,
Time to hide you: Father meeke
Give kind welcome, I beseeke,
To these white ones, bonny girles,
Welcommer than heaps of Pearles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheph.
SP.L: You see our Cave, and make as bold as welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Anto.
SP.P: Receive my adorations Queene of chance, Thou never gav'st that jewell to that man, was halfe so wel esteem'd; my hopes have their desires, Phemone, blest suc∣cesse; nothing that's amisse, but I shall understand: disguise I thanke thee, joy ties up my tongue, and will not let mee speake; they part not soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: What Angle of the Earth must be my grave?
The Sea and Sunne have bounds, and know their course,
The sonnes of men have none:
Limitlesse he wanders the forraigne desarts,
And begets more wonders every houre:
The Chime that tells the last minuite of the night,
Chides but in vaine when every thing's a sleepe;
So I in the relation of my woe, when no man hearkens,
Spend but idle breath, and never finde reliefe.
But for increase sake, I could wish devoutly,
I never had knowne woman:
What comfort ever others reapt from them,
They have beene plagues to me: to note the difference,
They are such things, nothing's more worse, nor better;
To say truth, they are Angels, and Devils;
I will not curse 'em, lest I make them worse
That needs no badnesse, nor rip up their defects,
Lest I spend all my after time of life in nothing else but that.
Iulio, the profit of my Orisona be thine,
Where e're I spend 'em, upright constant man:
Yet I am eas'd, in that I doe not beare my slavish yoake,
Cocker mine infamy, as many doe within our Venice gates:
Thanks to thee Iulio; Chastity, honour of women,
Whither art thou fled? that they are all so false
I must forget 'em, they will make me mad
To thinke of their abuse: would I could learne
What inquisition is made after me;
Some speech of my concealement will report blab out,
That I may heare the danger does pursue me,
Though I adventure life, I will know more,
Or dye in the presumption: I'le nearer to the City.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lodwick, Tomaso, Iulio, Stultissimo, Fub, the Whoore, and the Bawd.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: That's a good jest yfaith; Drawer, gives more Wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What's a good jest Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: That none should be honest but the valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: How's that? how's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Why my beetle-brow'd Host sweares 'tis impos∣sible for any to be honest, that is not valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: What said he? What said he?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: That none could be honest, that were not valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Tomd.
SP.L: O very good, very good: more Wine here, hee's packing, set out his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: And his foote too, ere I have done: where's this fellow? another Pottle sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Sir I thanke you for my powder, it gave her halfe a dozen of tickling stooles, she has beene loose ever since.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Give me your hand, here's even now to all the invi∣sible hornes i'th' City.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Forget not the Countrey, let it go round I pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: A health.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: You'le have reason to pledge this shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Will you come? to morrow is the day Ile assure you, for better or worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: To morrow from better to worse?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Yes faith he has said it, and I sweare it, from better to worse indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Married to morrow Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: You have said we shall be doing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Vndoing he meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.P: So neare marrying Clariflora, and not acquaint your friend? yfaith I thought Mistris you would have let me understood what had past.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.L: 'Tis my part to conceale.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: She were no good Bawd else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come, sit round, sit round, to morrow the day?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Pardon me, Ile not sit next this lousie fellow: gen∣tlemen, what doe you with this poore rogue in your compa∣nies? Does he come to make mirth, can hee play the foole wittingly?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I know him not.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Would he were set downe staires, I never could endure him from the first: Franciscus made me know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Sirra, if you meane to depart in peace, begon sud∣dainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Would the Asse could rid this intruding Copes∣mate.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Let me beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: You shall goe, your prayers cannot save you; Fub, shew him the way downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
