SP.L: Shall I be your Vsher? will you follow your lea∣der sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Thus poverty's despis'd at home, abroad, and in all companies.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: A whorson Tatred-demallion, come amongst Gen∣tlemen of sort. What, is't no more but up and ride? How now Fub, is he vanisht?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: The Drawers have drawne him out Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Clinke boyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Drinke boyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: And let the Cannikin clinke boyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Stultus.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Yes Lodwick.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Tomaso, shall's make a night on't mad lads?

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: And a mad night too Bullies: where shall's strike faile?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
The Leaguer, where but a'th' new Leaguer: there's
generous entertainment for Gallants of sort at all times: and for entrance trust me my mates.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: But money grows low, and expences will flye high.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Fly hye, let it, I have a jacke in a boxe shall pay for all one day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I am as full as a Spunge, I cannot sinke up a drop more.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: No matter, we can squeeze some more out thus: we can wake the Constable, trouble the neighbours, disquiet the Master and whole family, spill his Wine, puffe his To∣bacco, foule his roomes, practise who shall breake most holes, and cleanliest, in the bottome of quart-pots, with a piece of a Tobacco-pipe: cry good morrow mine Host, we ha' made a madde night on't I vow, and so trance; wee are no Gallants and we cannot doe this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: But this course is either conscionable, or commen∣dable.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Faith 'tis the course, most of the corke-headed Can∣dle-snuffes walke in these latter daies, late at nights.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Well, let them rest: So, ho, the Leaguer.

SP.SPEAKER: Munk.
SP.L: Chi-va-lah.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Amice.

SP.SPEAKER: Munk.
SP.L: The word.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Pecima largienda.

SP.SPEAKER: Munk.
SP.L: Let 'em passe: downe with the Percullis:
Lights and attendance, welcome Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I ever said, it might come in a night, that came not in an age, Et ecce noctem faelicem; see, that joviall night is come: They have beene playing high, and potting deepe: Lights, Wine, and more stooles for these Gentlemen; wel∣come.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lodowick, Tomaso, Stultissimo, and Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Tomaso when's the day?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Assure's this the night before to morrow, I have brought in my Estate a matter of 400 pound per annum, in Deeds, Leases, Fee-simple, and Coppy-hold already: and that's no simple Estate youle say: I meane to bid you welcome to a Leaguer of mine own shortly Gentlemen; some wine you Scondrils.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I'me pleas'd to here't, whose faults this, yours To∣maso?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: What's this Leaguer raysed yet, Par la ho boy, I thought we should have had a second siege of Troy on't, is their Reckoning paid? not a penny, they call'd for one, but in such a drunken key; I bad em sleep upon't, and I would tell em more on't when they were sober.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Best of all, and whats to pay then?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Nine and six pence, Sir, allowance for lights, lin∣nen, coals to light faggots: and six pence for one journymans sleep only deducted, and yet they grumbled too.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: But nine and six pence, and grumble; my friend the reckoning's not payd you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: Not a penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: The reckoning but nine and six pence, how poorely this shews, in a Leaguer too, and friends that pretended me a courtesie too? How many joynts of meat to supper?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Only a couple of clean Pipes, some three times fild I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: No meat, come to hansell a Leaguer, what no meat? Are they abed at Anthonies Ordinary yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Two houres ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Step down, and see, nine and six pence, they must and shall heare more of this: we may go beg, or buy up all the, refuse, broken bread and meat, scraps, offall, and garbage that Cooks shops, Shambles, Ordinaries, Entries, and Rich∣mens dores afford; nine and six pence, if they do not heare more of this—

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Tis past that time of night; Charitie's bed, sir, but if not.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bread.
SP.L: Bread and meat for poore prisoners, Bread & meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: What doth that fellow cry?

SP.SPEAKER: Bread.
SP.L: Bread and meat for the poor prisoners, bread & meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: For poore prisoners? as fit for my purpose, as a Con∣ny for a Pursnet; here, take mony, buy his provision by the lumpe: if I had studied for a fortune to fall upon me, I could not have had a fairer.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: Wilt thou victuall thy Leager with scraps, sweet Chuck?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: No, my sweet Monkie, I have further aymes then so, this broken meat and baggage offall, will I strew in my Kit∣chin, Dressers, Hall, Entries, and every doore and draw∣window, and perspicous places about the house: foule all the vessell, three or foure times over, all to besmeere the rustie spits and dripping-pans; breake all my broken glasses, beat the bottom out of my Cans: beat all my foul Tobacco-pipes, into fractions

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: And to what end all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Perlahay, My friends shall heare more of that in the reckoning: My sweet Monkie, when the Drunkards shall wake, and see all these ruines, or rather remayns of a plenti∣full Leager: Oh, hast thou no apprehension? Why, I tell thee, they cannot choose out of their generous bounties, but see all discharg'd?
SP.L: Within. A cup of six, Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Oh, the Leager begins to rise! Come Monkie a few directions for you in private, give you attendance on the Leager; let em call for what they will, and want nothing they call for: only I will tell em no more of nine and sixe pence in the reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: But for the nine and six pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: Monkie, you shall heare more of that anon, when they are sober? why Drawer, Dog, Dunghil-raker; is the Leaguer dry? By and by, a cup of six into the low Leaguer, there.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: So, ho, the Leaguer.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: What do ye lack? by and by, do ye call Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: No, and I call'd a Gentleman, he would answer me, I call a Drawer goodman Rascall, art thou one?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: For fault of a better, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Couldst not ha said so then? where's the Master of the Leaguet?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Parlahey Monkie, bene venu Gallants, com a stato Sigiores mio com I stato.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Marry the better for your entertainment; thanks, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Thank him, I scorn to thank him, Ile pay him, and be out of his debt: come, to pay? A reckoning Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: You Rascall, who takes away here? here's a house bestrewed with garbage and offall, as if the great Inquest had been feasted, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: As good men, to no mans disprayse be it spoken, where's a Bill?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: Prethee knock us not down, afore our time; was this certain feast of our making? what a spoyle of Poultery has here been? Tomso, I must be beholding to thee for this or∣dinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Some small trifle Stultissimo, the Reckoning is thought to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: The Reckoning's very high, nine pound six shil∣lings.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Nine pound six shillings, Parlahey, and yet I use you like Christians too boyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nine pound six shillings, how could wee foure de∣voure so much being halfe drunk when we came in?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Why there's the mistery? you fall asleep with meat in your mouthes, my Mistris and I stood it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: Wast not an excellent Swan-pie? Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: As ere swam in Mil-dam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nine pound six shillings, one lay out for all,
Come, your purses Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: And you love me, let me have the credit at this time there's: ten pounds, give me the rest again (ah, wee had the bravest Marchpane, and Sugar-candy Custard) or do not, let it run on towards fouling of linnen, and paying for sawee: the rest agen, or do—

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I do not think but you are sawst pretty well alrea∣dy, for the Devill a bit of meat saw I, and yet all these scraps could not come of nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: The Reckoning's paid to a haire, come let's with∣draw (but while the Room be a little finificald.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Parlahey, welcome Gallants to the Leaguer still: please you withdraw.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: We accept it thankfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Whose fault's this yours Tomaso?

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: There wants lap.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Throw downe the pottle pot, let's have a gallon more.

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Wilt please you Gentlemen, to heare any Musicke▪ and a good Song?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Very fain, a good one.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: What's your fellows, whose noyse are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fid.
SP.L: Ruberts noyse, and please you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Call your fellows, and strip your tools.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Here's to you Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: A brace of them if you love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Marry and shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Score a gallon of Claret in the Pomegranat.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: What Tim?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Master Fub I rejoyce to see you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: You are not merry Gentlewomen, Mistris Durable what, no mirth?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: And how ist, how have you done this seven yeares, welcome again.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: As you see, in perfect memory, when shall wee ride the hogsheads?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Ha, do you remember that night, Ancient Thumps health overthrew mee, my Master goes out of Towne next weeke; yfaith and youle come, there's halfe a dozen good boys, weele be swingeing merry, will give him a crash, old Will, Will be here?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: What Will?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Little Will of the Mitre. Oh, Master Fub, Sir, out Maid, that gave us the Neats Tongue is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: See, see.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Some Sugar there?

SP.SPEAKER: Fidler.
SP.P: Ha, ha, hum.

LG.L: In ample stories written tis,
Who list but for to minde it;
How loved Narcissus?
Go look and you shall finde it.
This Eccho was a Nymph most chaste,
A lack, the more the pitty▪
She should be so, and should not reape▪
What follows in my Ditty?
Narcissus was but young, I wisse,
But yet of perfect feature,
And had enough to satisfie
A reasonable creature.
His brawny limbes became his parts,
No one of sence could blame them:
And so did something else I trow,
Eccho knew how to name them.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: A vertuous piece of matter, Gentlemen, wee'le no more on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nay, hold up, Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Bid her hold up, feare not me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come Gentlewomen, shall we have a dance? Tomaso what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: You prevented me.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: I thought it should have been my motion?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Wherefore ring those bels?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Bels, you are deceived, it is the clincking of pots.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I would have sworn, it had been Coronation day.
Masters, can you play us Gascoynes Whibling?

SP.SPEAKER: Fidler.
SP.L: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Let's ha't.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Here lacks a couple, we cannot dance it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Lack a couple, what serve Tim and I for?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Tis true, well remembred.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Truly, Master Fub, I cannot dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Truly, you shall learn then.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: I shall be willing to endevour.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: Strike.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Ile throw the pot at his head that strikes heere,
Whose that will strike?

DIV1.STAGE: Hee drinks all the while they dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Rare yfaith, give's more wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: What, Timothy?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: By and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.L: Look to the Lion.

DIV1.STAGE: He rises and throws down the table.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Ile have my Galliard too

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: You spoyle all.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.L: How does your head, sweet heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Yes faith, and thank you too, what Rogue's he that turns the Room round? shall we not quench our thirsts be∣fore we part?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What else my sweet Signior, this is your servant?

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: Good enough for a property, he will serve my turn, as well as a better, I shall but use his name: do you think I would marry the Coxcombe, but only for colour and feare of the Law? I'de see him bak'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.L: Tis wisely done of you? and so my Gossip Slight could say I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Boy, another quart, and bring a Reckoning. Here sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fidler.
SP.L: Heaven keep your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: In honester company.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Fub, call for a Looking-glasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Did you go the right way?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: It's a cup of neat wine, Ile assure—

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Mistris to your self, and to our next meeting?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: What's to pay?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Nine and six pence, and you're welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: How comes that to passe?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Here's seven groats Glasses.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: No lesse, Ile assure your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come your mony, Signior—

DIV1.STAGE: Let's take away and pay together.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Fub, discharge it Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: Some lights, shew the Gentlemen.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter and follow with a letter from Vallentius.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Fub, I am ene as full as a Toad.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Yes, sir, but do not spit your venome.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Prethee give mee another sip. I am as dry as a Cook.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: So I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: A pox a this Megrum.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What's here, I prethee marke Tomaso: Lodwick, I have my desire: fetch mee off speedily, lest I cure the Do∣ctour? yours Vallentius, lest I cure the Doctour.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: What should he mean by this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Why, belike he has infused his fit into him, and the Physician's turn'd Patient?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: That's impossible?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: But for Ʋallentius.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: We must redeem him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What else.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Heyda, is the winde in that door?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: A link good Tim, a link.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: Here's one ready, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Signior, good night.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Not a drop more yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Wee'le take our leaves.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.L: When shall we see you?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Somtime to morrow, if my father send not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SP.L: Good night Master Lodwick, good night good, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Good night Tim, remember Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: I warrant you, forget not to bring Hugh, Welcome Gentlemen.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus quartus. Scena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter the Doctor and his Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I Speak't in thunder once again, no more: thou Babylo∣nian Strumpet, in thunder I command thee thou lump of sinne, no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Have patience, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: I rore it in thy eares, once more aloud, no more: cannot I deale, but you must be applying, you must be tam∣pering, you must minister: have you not Pils for Potions? do you not traffique? do not you exchange Merchant?

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Good Vanderman.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Sorceresse, I defie thee, and thy deeds of darknes.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Heare me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: I have heard and seen too much, has hee not paid you soundly for your pains: no, has he popt you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.P: You are deceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: You say very true, I am deceived indeed, and Fub'd, and Guld, and Rid, and you are Rid too.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: What meane you?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Here blow it abroad, there's horns enow to do't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Why are you thus impatient?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Dainty fine y faith, very dainty. Whore thou hast made me monstrous, and I may challenge Gyants: Yes, he shall be your mad-man; Doe you not like his fits, doe you not, doe you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Amb.
SP.L: God morrow to you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Why should this be?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: How doe you sir? how does your patient?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Are you not satisfied? am I a stale? must you have new-found Crochets?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Doe you heare me sir: is he recovered▪

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Homo Armatus, a man armed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Have you heard the like?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Me thinks 'tis excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Doc.
SP.L: And when, when shall he plant againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I wish you would understand me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Here's a fruitfull soyle.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom:
SP.L: Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Sir, I will be heard, and understood:
Save you Lady:

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: More furies, might, and secresie, whoredome and The every bring all to confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Would we had more of this: we'le see what will come of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I perceive Vallentius was i'th' right, he's madde in∣deede:

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Good Morrow Gentlemen: I have good newes for you; your friend is well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Your tidings makes us happy, and gives us a moyetie of that content which nothing can doe more.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.P: I shall rejoyce to see him what hee was, and Master of that temper he commanded, when he did dare the vaunting Ba∣jeset for taxing his beliefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Tomaso, Lodwick.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Valentius.

SP.SPEAKER: Toma.
SP.L: I am glad to see you once again your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: You're welcome to your wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋal.
SP.L: When time and place shall serve, my wit shall thanke you I am ever bound to you sweet Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Harke you Lodwick, are not we partly Bawds?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Faith in one kinde, we have a snatch that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: So I say partly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I must confesse, partly.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Not remember you, have not that bad opinion, doe not think I can be one so false by this kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Sibylla.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Ay me, my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Once again and part.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Sibylla.

SP.SPEAKER: Wife.
SP.L: Farewell, Valentius.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: A thousand take with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: What, hungry still Vallentius, that you cast such a greedy eye that way?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: How ist man? what in a trance?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: And kinder far then faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: What, shall we have a Pamphlet; that he begins to stu∣dy? doe you heare Ʋalentiuss: here's a friend of yours would speak with you, when you are at leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I crave your pardon Gentlemen, as I live she is—

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What's this to the purpose?

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Julio, and the Mercer with his man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: You know my price: for the finenesse of the silke, the working of the stuffe, and the pleasantnesse of the colour, the whole street shall not afford you a better, Ile assure you tis died in grain.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: The better for him that shall wear it, nothing but what's in grain can please him: let mee see, I know not how my mony will reach: the Silkman hath emptied my pocket this morning, but you will bate nothing of your price?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.L: I protest sir, I cannot, and save by it, and I know you would not wish me to be a loser.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: By no means, I would have every man to live & thrive by what he professeth, it is mine owne case: let me see, I cannot make up the sum, I pray you let one of your men step over to the next lane: I lie there at the Barbers, Ile dispatch him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: My servants are all busie for the present, you see my shop is full of Customers, and every one striveth who shall be first served.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: And I am in haste too, for I have sent for my Tailor to meet me at my lodging, and I am loth to disappoint him, because I would have his opinion in the stuffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.L: I pray you, sir, be expeditious, and my man shall be with you by that time you have told out the mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: I am much obliged to you as a stranger, I care not if I accept—

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.L: Dispatch me that Customer quickly, and follow this Gen∣tleman to his lodging: you heare where he lies.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Yes, at the next turning?

SP.SPEAKER: Mercers man.
SP.L: Ile but fold up this boult of Sattin, and be with him instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Turne by the next lane, and thou shalt be sure not to misse it, though thou findest not me, I have took sufficient order and you shall be sure to be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.L: We have many cheapners, but few buyers, many such customers as this would make quick riddance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mercers man.
SP.L: What comes the summe to, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Three yards of Sattin and a halfe at seventeene, eight yards of Plush at foure and twenty; nay, there are divers other parcels, the summe is soon cast up: thou shalt have a note of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mercers man.
SP.L: And Ile but fold up these few boults lie loose, and cleere the counter and be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.L: Be quick there.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: But thou must be secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: As your self, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: A pretty handsome youth, and will be loath to discover himselfe, being extreamly bashfull, and will make it strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: Leave him to me, Ile perswade him that I knew him, ere I saw him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Hee's my Kinsman, next Cousin German's by the Mo∣thers side; now playing the Wag, as many youths will doe, you know it Barber.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: Very well, it hath been many a good mans case.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: He hath got a clap.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: These claps are got by clapping.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: But for one thing, never should it grieve mee, I feare it might go nere to spoile his marriage, which I would not for more than Ile speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: You shew your self a Kinsman.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Now his exuse will be (as I told thee he's extreamly bash∣full) to enquire for a Gentleman that owes his Master mony, to comply with the old Proverbe, Though his excuse be draff, yet drinks his errand.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: And lotion must be used.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: As it shall seem best: but thinkst thou hee'l endure it.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: 'Twill put him to some pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Which Ile not heare, my heart's so tender ore him: when he comes (as long hee will not stay) take him in charge, Thy pains shall be well paid, for doubt not but Ile come to the conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: Very good, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: My hope is it will succeed according to my wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: Make no doubt of that, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: If I had, I had not made choice of thee above any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: You are my friend indeed: and so I hope to keep you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: I will withdraw for the present, and instantly return.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.P: Now good speed with you, good customers are thicke sowed, and come up but thin. It is good to make much of them, when we have them. This should be the patient, that he talked off.

SP.SPEAKER: Mercers man.
SP.L: I come to seek a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: You do: that owes your Masters mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: Very true, sir, you know my errand then.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: Before you came.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: The Gentleman belike hath told it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: He hath indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: Is he within?

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: But before he went, left order with me, you should be dispatcht.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: Then I shall find him as good as his word: he hath acquainted you with my occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: Ile assure you that, and intends well towards you, I pray come neer into the withdrawing Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: Ile wait on you, pray know you what it comes too.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.P: Yes youth, I know, wherfore you come: pray rest you in that chaire, and Ile be for you presently; be not ashamed, you are not the first, nor shall be the last, that meet with these disa∣sters: and now come, pray shew me your commodity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: The commodity belongs, sir, to my Master, 'twas not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.P: Are his in danger too? let him not feare, but if hee have not let it run too far, there may be helpe found: nay, come, will you shew?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: Mean you the note: there are the parcels sent.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.P: These parcels may in time grow great, come, will you be ruled, the Gentleman your Kinsman, told mee before, how bashfull you would be; and it becomes you well: but for your parcels, shew them in time: for if delay be long, that little which perhaps you shall have left, in time will come to nothing: your Kinsman's loth that you should spoile your Marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.P: Spoile my Marriage, spoile not my Masters debt, Neither draw these fearfull tricks on me: I need them not, pay mee the mony that your friend hath left, Dispatch mee so, for Kinsman I have none; And honest Barber finde some else to sport with, make me none of your Guls?

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.L: But I pray say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.P: I say, pay me sir, what's my due, & what by your con∣fession, your friend left, or bring me to the party, or commodity he late had of my Master, or Coine for't: you have confest him to be your friend, therfore for him must answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.P: By your favour, no more friend of mine, then you found him, to claime Kinred: my acquaintance with him, yet is scarce a full houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.P:
You are Confederates, and so I feare that I shall finde you: You know my errand, & promist mee dispatch:
Why am I not dispatched then?

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.P: My meaning was to give you a Sering, or an incision Knife, Of which he told me you did stand in need: Indeed I deal in such cōmodities, And am acquainted what such parcels mean: For other wares or mony due for them, I know not what be∣longs to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer. man.
SP.L: Satisfie my Master so, quit me, and cleer thy self; or 'twill fall foule upon thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Barb.
SP.P: Willingly: my cloak boy, Ile along, yet am affraid That hee who had profest himselfe thy Kinsman, and my deare friend, will prove thy Masters Cosin.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lodwick, Tomaso, Stulitssimo, Monky, Puss, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Puss.
SP.L: Give you joy Master Stultissimo; give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: You talk like Gentlemen, and I like your talk the bet∣ter, because you talke to a Gentlemen; you call mee Stultissimo, and I say, Stultorum plena sunt omnia: and now I talk to you like a Gentleman and a Scholer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: All health and joy betyde you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Gramercy Gentlemen, I am not now the man, I was in the morning; I did rise single, I return double: in the Meridian but Worshipfull, in the afternoon Honorable before Sun-set, and who knows but Majesticall before mid-night: nay I perswade my self I am so: am I not sweet Monkie?

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: Thou art my deare Baboon.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Very pretty names in faith: I prethee let's enterchange them still betwixt us: or Marmoset, or Apes face.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: Yes, yes, by any means.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: All thy goods and chattels, thy moveables, and the stuff that belongs thereto, thy utensils and implements; now are all mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Monk.
SP.L: They are, to have and to hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Puss.
SP.L: Yes, as long as yee can keep them.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: I have purchased thee in thy proper person by my word, but all thy other omnium gathrum, beforenamed, by my deeds, I think thou hast them to shew.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: The minde gives sometimes words unto the tongue, and makes it speak perforce, beare with him Lodwick.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
Let the Doctors wife beare with him, for mine own part,
without he renounce this mood, and become sociable, as hee had wont, I defie his fellowship.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Will you dine with me Vallentius?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Yes, shall we be merry?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P: O is the tide turn'd, is the winde come about, by this good day, and I were not cursing my selfe, for being accessary to this melancholy, I have no faith in me; if women can transmute men thus suddenly, hang me, if I keep not out of their clutches.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Gallants, shall wee walk? I have a story for ye: prethee Lodwick frown not, be a friend indeed, and see not my defects, I have a tale shall make you laugh anon, and will excuse my blame; prethe be thy selfe, be jocund man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nay, I am soon perswaded.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Where shall we be?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: At the old house.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Come then, I'le make you laugh I sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Thus by degrees, with hazard of my life, have I attain'd unto my wishes rest; and boldly gaze thee Venice in the face: the time has beene, Oh, but that time is past, when I was more familiar with thy pompe, but all that blisse is gone: And murther now, has with a crimson stain seal'd mee accurst, and like a con∣demn'd guilty Fugitive; I wander in despaire; fearing the rule of the harmlesse bird, and the flies clamor, the Ant, the Waspe, and every lesser thing, Dreadlesse of danger, strayes abroad for food; Not caring who behold them, But I, alas, of all; am most unhappy: Would I were dead, and past the feare of that, Makes mee thus Cowish. Who art thou comm'st here, more needy then my self?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Where might I run to meet destruction, And set a period on my wretchednesse? Stern misery I know, and feele thee now: Yet is the earth content to beare my weight, And suffer what proud man disdains to know, Unlesse to spit upon, or add to that, Which wanteth no extream.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I cannot hold: his voice, his humour, I dare sweare as much, 'tis he; 'Tis he by heaven, my Iulio.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Franciscus, preserver of my life; O let mee kisse the ground whereon thou treadest, then rise to thank thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
That I could spend my self to teares for joy, beare wit∣nesse you that know it: Iulio, for ever dwell within these arms
of mine, thou truest among men, I have not power to question thee, my danger, my joy is so excessive; runne all to spoyle, & terrour meet with terrour; I feare none my Julio.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: Strike when thou wilt proud death, I dare thee now; For having what I wisht, I wish no more, nor would entreate time to deferre a minuite to have him rest an age, since all things must have end, end it at once, my prayer is confirm'd, I have seene you e're I die.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: And if you love me wish me not that wrong by pray∣ing for your end: doe not quite undoe me, if you but knew my heart, my Julio, you would not crav't againe: I could have com∣fort now, and cleane forget the dangers I have past, and those pursue me still: nothing to come can halfe so much dismay, as thou dost comfort; be it suddaine death or torture worse than it: but for your sake, would in my wombe I had bin strangled, and never drawne this aire.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: Where art thou Conscience? whither hast thou tooke Since thou didst leave mans breast? that wee should all have mothers; VVisedome all, yet all contemne her precepts: when you first fled, and by command'ment from the Senate house, your ships and lands were siez'd on for the State, those that which staid them did appeare so neare, as if their blood had ty'd them to your service, grew so forgetfull in a mo∣ments space, that neither argument, nor extreame signes could winne them to beliefe there had beene such, as what you were to them: I (as no lesse I could) bound to't by duty, spoke your merits still, and did maintaine your right, on the Allyes of your inconstant wife: but I am poore for't, truth was still despis'd, and lesse I could not be.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Take all I have▪ had I my former wealth,
My bounty could not recompence thy worth,
And powre it all before thee (my deare Iulio:)
Be not impatient with thy sufferance, he's above wil pay thee all
My debts, though I should perish now.
Contemn'd for me? alack, alack, if there be such
A thing in Charity, be charitable: doe not curse the cause
Of this thy present want, I doe beseech thee doe not thou Iulio?
I prethee answer me, and either doe what I have wisht,
Or cure the wound thou hast made.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Good sir no more: doe not call all the teares out of mine eyes; think who I am: would you did but know.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I will not urge thee further:
Shall we here combine, and shape our course alike,
And never, never part; yet pardon me,
I will not wish thee so much injury
To be unknowne of woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: You wish me not so well, how e're you wish, if you wish otherwise: your misery be mine, and my enduring yours; one grave receive our bones; and hee that sayes this Sepulcher is mine, call it Francisco's Tombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I have a habite for thee yet unknowne, or worne,
But by my selfe: 'tis not a Furlong from the Antique Beech,
Whose hollow sides conceales it: bide but here,
Till I can reach it from the hidden place,
And take it for thine owne: though homely,
Yet the coursenesse will keep warme,
And ward the sharpest blast.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: You binde me to my prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Ile be with thee straight.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Ignorant honesty, shallow Italian, yes, live a wretch: Canst thou be so fond to thinke me of that mettle? hast thou eyes, and mayst, yet will not see how thou art o're-recht: yes, doe continue innocent, doe, and die a foole, my friend, my friend, my very loyall friend, all friendship I forsweare, save outward signes, which with my garment J cast nightly off. The father of the slaine Antonio promises liberally by Proclamation to any that can bring Francisco forth. I will betray him, I will be the man shall purchase the reward: What way I curses, or care for the report the multitude shall clamour therein. Ile imitate the Lawyer, making bad words my gaine. Franciscus thou wast born for my advancement: he's sunke himselfe, and fruitlesse is the hope depends on that which was, and not which is; give me the present, not precedent man. Let me not hanker for emergency, but take the instant sway, the publish't recompence is mine, 'tis sayd, 'tis mine.

DIV1.STAGE: Franciscus puts a coat upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: That any should be false—But were there no drosse, gold could not be esteem'd, nor nothing precious rare. Cornelia let me forget that name and nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: It is a month and more since she left Venice.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Would I had left the world when I first saw her.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: And the same minuite did Phemone forsake her friends and kindred: but where or whither they have betook themselves the most knowing but conjecture.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: How easie could wee make our miseries, if wee might live and dye when't pleas'd our selves?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: These strange additions to my newes I add, Antonio's Carkasse never could be found since yours and his contention.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I left him dead: thou art still just; some beast has made that fouler beast his prey, and made up my revenge: but come with me, let us withdraw unto you thicket by, and speake at large that woefull history commixt of my proceedings, and pur∣suith; wilst time's our owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: I would provide me of some necessaries, small in ex∣pence, which make a mighty misse, and health cryes out to have: so if you please but let me fit my present want, at my returne en∣joyne me to your will, though it continue to the latest date, and I am serviceable.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Speake no more such words, but make your owne con∣tent: yet good Iulio be not absent long, make me not long to see thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Such shall be my speed, you will not wish me sooner to returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Not wish thee? yes, though thou shouldst make return e're thou depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Marke the end.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
Be briefe, and goodnesse take with thee. This Iulio, if desert might purchase Fame, deserves sufficient: but thou art par∣tiall Fortune in cramming Buzzards, whilst the Eagle sterves: How many in this fertile Italy, whom Nature moulded when she loath'd her taske, and blew her seed among the ignorant, hast thou adorn'd with plenty? whilst seemely vertue, wrackt with poverty, jets under base controule: There's no felicity, nor true content here upon earth: The Spider builds his Webbe in Barnes and Palaces: and the Prince himselfe tastes gall as hony: Happinesse there's none, for least or greatest: Here my griefe so parches me, that it does paine me to relate my woes, and make my feelings knowne. Beneath this Hill a cleare and pleasant
fountaine curles along, whose shallownesse makes the small pibbles 'peare above like Rocks, and murmure as shee runnes downe to the silver Current, thither will I high, and borrow so much of her watry store, as will asswage my thirst:
SP.L: All things are kinde,
And feed our wants when they themselves are pin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Now my Catter-whauling Pusse, how didst thou like my last Cheat? did I not foole them finely?

SP.SPEAKER: Pusse.
SP.L: Thou art the very meere Mephostophelus, and I per∣swade my selfe thou hast new vampt thy wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Tush these are nothing: I have cheated one of the bra∣vest Stats-men of the world; the very quintessence of Spaine: Nay, I have fool'd him who boasted in his Country, he had guld all our Nation A Guelding is not rid in the horse-faire, but hee is mine to ride, maugre his Masters teeth. I have out-fac'd a fellow of his horse in the open Market, sold him before his face; & but making a question whether he trots or ambles, ride away both with the horse and mony, my Pusse. Sweet Munkey looke to the house at home, I must abroad againe, to fetch in a new purchase.

SP.SPEAKER: Pusse.
SP.L: Maist thou thrive according to thy will, and to my wishes.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Stultissimo, Lodwicke, Tomaso, and two Sorieants.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serg.
SP.L: And what's your Action?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Three hundred pound: bee you ready to snappe him, and not to escape you without good baile: he's as slippery as an Eele.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serg.
SP.P: Therefore we'le take him by the shoulder, and not by the taile; and so we shall be sure to hold him. But can you shew us the man?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: This is his walk, and without waiting long you may spye him.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Say but that's he, and 'tis enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Stand as close as you can: If he have but the least suspi∣tion of an arrest, he's gone in a twinkling.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ser.
SP.L: But will not you stay and assist us?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P:
By no meunes; Ile but see him in hucksters handling, and be gone. Are you not paid your Fees afore-hand, and—
That's he now: Now let him scape upon your owne perrill. Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: If he doe, say no more: Yeo man stand to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Now let me see: whom shall I next encounter?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Marry the Counter sir: for we arrest you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Ha, Counterfeits so nigh?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serg.
SP.L: Yet currant enough to carry you to prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: And yet your Counter-tenour sounds but like scurvy Musicke: am I catcht then? I pray you at whose fuite?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: At three mens suite.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Then three merry men, and three merry men be we, are we not honest Serjeants? well, there's a peece to begin with∣all: lets talke further of the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.P: You speake well sir, if you hold on as you beginne: and if you can finde good baile, tenne to one but we shall prove as you late cald us (Honest Serjeants.)

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Me thinks you doe not speak like Varlets:

DIV1.STAGE: Enter a grave Doctor in serious discourse with a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: May it please you, sir, to imploy mine industry For any further service?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Something more,
Which in my former Letter I forgot,
I would entreat you beare in memory:
And that's but this—

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: And in good time: Know you that reverend man?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Know him sir, yes, for a worthy Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: He's mine owne Vncle: will you take his word.
And make it to me as a free discharge?
If he but say (nay there's another peece)
Ile see you satisfied?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serg.
SP.L: Yes could we heare him say so: for hee's one whose word will not be questioned.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: 'Tis enough:
Give me but so much leaue as speake unto him,
All Ile keep in faire distance: on my life,
If he ay not Ile see you satisfied,
I will returne your prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L:
'Tis enough: for so farre we dare trust you: you have
paid for't well: but we will watch him at an inch.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: I know he will not suffer mee to lye
For such a petty summe: Now braine or never.
Excuse my boldnesse Sir: though it be scarce manners,
To interrupt your serious conference.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: With me sir is your businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Such a businesse,
Which as it toucheth me in Charity,
So should it you in Conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Speake it pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.L: Look well on these two men.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: He poynts at us.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: The one is an arch Brownist, and the other
Cannot endure to see a Surplesse worne:
Subject indeed to no conformity;
Yet both so well perswaded of your learning,
And spotlesse life, that what you shall propose
Th'are willing to subscribe too.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: I am as ready to give them my instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.L: And please you say so, that they may heare you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Well I will:
My honest friends, and please you to have the patience
Till I have ended with this gentleman,
And instantly Ile see you satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: It is enough grave sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Now honest Serjeants: what desire you more?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serg.
SP.L: Nothing from you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: I hope so honest Serjeant: you see I deale fairely.
Farewell my honest Serjeants.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: I have told you all: only remember me to these my no∣ble friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.L: With all the art
My weake tongue can deliver.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sergeant.
SP.L: So, he is now at leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: And now I come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Most welcome, sir, we stay for the same purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Now, tell me briefly, which of you is the Brownist?
which the other, cannot indure a Surplice?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serg.
SP.L: You are pleasant, sir,
We waite here, hoping to be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: And to that end I stay, for these opinions
So erroneons and so grosse.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Sir, all the opinion that we hold is that you will pay us the mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Still obstinate in errour; 'tis this mony,
And worldly care on which so much you doate:
Breeds in you these distractions.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Please you to pay the mony, you shall finde us confor∣mable in all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Mony my friends, are not you Sectaries?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serg.
SP.L: Sectaries; no, sir, we are Sergeants.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Sergeants; and waite for me? I owe you mony?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Yes, sir, for your Nephew that was with you but now, and told you of it; & we heard you say, you would see us satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: The man's to me a stranger I protest,
And his request was I should satisfie you
In some points of Religion.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Religion, sir, 'tis a theam we seldome think of,
But three hundred pound is mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: But I tell you,
I past my word for counsell not for coine,
And this is all that you from me can have:
Endure a Surplice, and beware a Knave.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Serg.
SP.L: Had we not warning sufficient of this before?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Well, howsoever, we have had good counsell,
If we had the grace to follow it.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus quintus. Scena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Arbaces, and Julio in good apparell, with three or foure with weapons.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.L: ASsure me of the promist recompence, I'le bring you to his presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Heare me a word.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Vallentius, Lod wick, Tomaso, Stultissimo and Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Now Signior, how do you feele you selfe? How like you marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Faith it's a pretty quaint thing, and there's much good sport belongs to't, would I were unmarried again?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Why? are you weary of Clariflora already?

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Weary no, but I would have store.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.P: Harke you, sir, take my counsell; though store be no sore, meddle with no more of them, lest you make me a Prophet, and get many a sore head by the match: have you not heard the an∣cient saying, No man can serve two masters?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: That's true, but any man may serve two Mistresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: And serve their turns well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Nay, i'le leave that to the performer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Hark you Master Lodwick, you or any man may thinke he does well, and yet come short.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Briefly, directly, and learnedly spoken, sweet Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: I speak by proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Go to, your are a Knave Fub.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Hold your peace, there's more in the company.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Well said, yfaith, thank him Lodwick.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: It's not worth it, though I should say as much by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: This fellow flows with wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.P: Gallants, when were you at Court? I have been desired thether fortie times, my wife (I thinke) has a hundred friends there: besides Cooks and Pantlers, that she has had many a good thing of, and they have sworn to bid me welcome for her sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: You may see what comes by marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: If we might see all that comes by marriage, there would be old butting abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Here's the summe, perform thy word, and claime it.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Good morrow, good Arbaces.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Make me not known to these?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Vallentius.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Are you not mad, I heard no lesse of late.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Report's a calumnious quean, and will abuse vertue it self you see, both what he is, and what he was?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: I am not sorrie, that I am deceiv'd: heare you not of Franciscus.

DIV1.STAGE: Exit Arbaces with Julio, and the Watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Upon my credit nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Faire be your companie, come Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What's he that throws his Cloake about his nose?
Is it not Iulio?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: By all exterior seeming?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: My life 'tis he?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What should this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I was asking that.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Mark't you Arbaces: he hath some drift in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Did you not note his followers?

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Yes, and the Arms they carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Shall we trace them, firs? and leave our wonder: I dare gage my life, the knowledge will deserve the industry?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: You speake my words.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Hee named Franciscus.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Yes, and question'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Withall, observ'd you but his speed.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Come, wee will pursue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: La, la, la, la: nay, I pray take me with you Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: If not for company, for mirth's sake, take heed before there.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: In mightie men how great appears the vertue nere so small; how small the vice, though mighty Philosophie, they rules bridles my cogitations, and prolongs, what manhood would disdain, the time to come appales my courage and strikes instant feares through every nerve and artery: might wee like beasts end when wee die, and never make account in no other place then heer: what heart so base would feare the threatning Law? Flatter the Judge to save him: I would not sure: but there is blisse and torment much to come, wee cannot thinke on't yet the Re∣surrection aws me, I am much distempered, and want of compa∣nie, begets in me millions of terrours: Iulio tarries long, my Orisons secure him, could the teares wash the bloud but of my hands, my minde were something free.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Julio mufled, Arbaces and a Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.L: This is the place, and there Franciscus walks.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: That's he: apprehend him, i'le not be seen in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Your office, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: What are these for men.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Lay hands upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: What mean you friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Constable.
SP.L: This we mean to attach you, as a murderer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Arbaces, I am betray'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.P: Look to the homicide, such mercie as a Tiger yields his prey, when he's pincht for want of what's his booty, expect from me thou murtherer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: None I have deserv'd, or am about to crave, I know the worst, my life thou canst but have, 'Tis thine; I make a tender of it ere the sentence come, & give thy labour ease, alas, poor Iulio: thou wilt unfriended, run thy future race without societie, I pitty thee my friend more then my selfe, danger to me is such, I do expect and dread not. Fare thee well, my breach of promise, is not with my will, but meerly on constraint.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Lead him hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Here they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Who have we here bound to the good behaviour? Fran∣ciscus!

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: My deare friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: My brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Officers, why doe you linger thus, away with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋal.
SP.L: How fare you, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Sicke, sicke to death Vallentius: shall wee hence?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: I now behold my feare, when I did heare Arbaces speak of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Something of badnesse shoot me instantly, but hee does pierce me through.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Good Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Has he recided here since he first fled?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: I thought him now in Millain, where hee did trafficke much.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I wonder how he came to be discovered?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Beshrew my bloud, I pitty his estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Will you accord with mee, shew that respect you once did tender him, and withall willingnes strive to invent a means may do him ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: What, my sword, my word, or wealth can doe is his, command it for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Let us petition to his rough adversary, and like true Sup∣pliants in our own behalfs, draw mercy from Arbaces.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: About it then, and our intentions thrive. Manet Julio.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: The gold is mine, his certain bondage does assure mee it, why should I be an Asse, and nicely stand on that no Trades∣man does: no thrifty one, what conscience, any thing but such a word: our wise divines that preach an't, know it not, nor make good use of that, or ought they say, but of good mony: this I dai∣ly see, and sometime make my daily meditation, all's Ceremonie compos'd for purpose:
SP.L: But be it what it will, this is my grace,
If not for one, I'me for the othe place.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter the Duke of Venice, two Senators, Crissipus, Arbaces, Vallentius, Tomaso, Lodwick, Clarke, and others.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Bring the offender forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Have mercie, good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: Believe't thou mayst sooner move a rock, which nei∣ther blustring winde, nor boisterous Sea could shake or swal∣low, then beget remorse or smallest favour in so foule a case: I were unjust, and much unmeet to be the man I am, should wee shew mercie where the crime deserves, beyond the laws extent. He that shall pardon murder, take't from me, is accessary to the guilty deed, and stands in self predicament: Heaven defend we should be such, were he my Nephew, nay, my first-borne sonne, or one more neere: let me not be blest in my proceedings, if our Authoritie should blinde his sinne, or alter justice course, set him forth: what favour equitie can yield be his, no more expect Crisippus.

SP.SPEAKER: Pri. Sen.
SP.L: Read the indictment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Save that pains, guilty, nor do repent, that in my wrath I did, whereof I stand convict.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Art thou not sorrie for thy hainous crime?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: No mighty sir, but rather joy the more, in that it bre∣viats my passage here, which I would willingly leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Impudent homicide: justice good my Lord, with that severitie which they deserve, which wilfully commit—

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P:
Arise, thou needst not kneele, nor beg for justice, be assu∣red Arbaces: such his deservings, such his punishment, and cruell
as the cause, thou most bruitish man, nay, beast or something worse: hadst thou no humanitie, no sparke of reason then, nor sence, to thinke thy trespasse foule and ugly? do'st not repent thy tyranny in death, though not the deed it self: fie on thee monster, hast thou a foule and dreadst not her perdition: what heathen sa∣vage, nay, what ruder thing, having the life thou soughtst, would have enacted such a deed of ruth, as thou, thou worst of crea∣tures, on the image and livelesse carcasse of thy loving friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Pri. Sen.
SP.L: 'Twas most uncivill, most unchristianly.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sen.
SP.L: An act, a Tigre would not have perform'd, on one that had slain his brood.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Heare me good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: My poore Antonio.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: That I did take his life, I have confest, what further accusations laid on mee, is meerly malice, and proceed from some, could wish my torment worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Out on thee butcher: give me leave my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Clark.
SP.L: Silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Canst thou deny thy wrathfull crueltie, impetuous ty∣ranny, and fell revenge upon his bleeding trunk?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Unlesse I should belie my selfe, and speake like a vaine boaster, more then what I did, I must say this is false, and hee's from truth, as farre as I am from hope of life, begot this slander.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Produce your proofe Arbaces, strike blushes through the cheeks of this false man, and let him see his shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: What Devill should be rais'd from the lowest hell, to justifie this wrong?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: This is strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: I never thought Franciscus one so foule, as I behold him now.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Not thought, I durst have sworn him of a purer mettle▪ and better temper farre.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Prosperitie to the Venetian State.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Iulio: he's not his proof I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Is this the Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: This is he my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Make room, give way there.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: How comes this about?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sen.
SP.P: The fact's confest, my Lord, what need we further wade into the Law, or heap on troubles which we may eschew, upon so plain a case? the crime is Murder, Murder is confest, then as you finde the guilt, proceed to judgement, and make no further question.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: We shall be suddain.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: My sentence, good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: Speake, sir, can you report any thing more touching this businesse then what already is delivered here in the open Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: No more or lesse, then what his owne tongue uttered, can I or have to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: How's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: We were once friends: once had I such opinion of his vertues, my life and estimation were both his, hee might com∣mand them, much it were to speake of all that past between us: thus in short, I would some other were compell'd to this, which you have tied me too, my neerest friend alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Arbaces: was this the man gave you first notice where this Murderer kept?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: The same my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Did he betray me? can this be.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sen.
SP.L: Forward.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sen.
SP.L: Speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Must we be enforc'd, what should I speak, hee flue him, ript his bowels, mangled him, and in his wrath, as man will any thing: tumbled his reeking quarters downe a Vault most steep and lothsome: what of this, hee might deserve much worse au∣steritie, yet this was bad enough?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: Justice, gracious Prince, justice, justice, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Is this truth?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Let me be depos'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: The most erronious, execrable part that ever was per∣form'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Were hee my father, should forget himselfe, and match this outrage, mercy quite forsake me if I would sue his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: It was ruthlesse, fell, and bloudie.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Look not up for shame, thou hast no interest there.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I have done wrong, mightie, mightie wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Canst thou behold it now?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Pardon me father, pardon good Arbaces: that villaine, that foule villaine.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Antonio, Cornelia, Phemone, and Shepheard.

SP.SPEAKER: Antonio.
SP.L: 'Twas time to come.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.L: Shew mercie, mercie, Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.L: Pittie our complaints, have some compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: What are these that make this earnest deprecation, with such a heartie zeale; are they well known to this assembly?

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: Cornelia, sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Faire Phemone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: When will these humid fountains be dried up, and yield no more warme drops?

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.L: My sweet Franciscus.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Some good or bad thing fell mee suddenly, let mee be∣hold no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Is that his wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: She was my Lord, while some hard fate dis-joyn'd their mutuall league, and burst the holy concord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Wilt thou pardon me and live a happie one, when I am dead, and lapt in this cold earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cor.
SP.L: Franciscus I was ever true to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I see it, and believe: that villaine, oh, that villaine!

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Harken thy sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
Heare mee my good Lord, little I have to say, yet to much grief tend my few words, this traitor, nay, 'tis title all too good for one so hainous foule, that he is perjur'd, by the death I owe his latest words do witnesse what hee is more, and worse: with pardon Lords, I shall delate at large, that all hereafter may example take, and shun a villaines snare; I tooke him up, when like an Adder in the frosty dew, the cold had starved him: that I had set my foot upon his head, when to my bosome I did take the Serpent, not cherisht, comforted long had he been, but hee both bit and stung mee: foolish man I was to be so fond, not many months, nor happy days I had with this most truest, most immaculate piece, but that perfidious Caitiffe, that blacke fiend by strange suggestions, and invented projects, draws mee into a confirm'd jealousie, that she had stained her honour, falsly playd
with young Antonio.

SP.SPEAKER: Anton.
SP.L: O forgive me heaven, what is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I from my wrong conceiv'd, least could I not, Drew him apart into a silent Grove, Having before vow'd solemnly revenge, Where I made some repetition of my griefe: he still (I see him) innnocent gentleman, taking my words For such as Lovers use, when they are wanton, Smiles me in the face, and would not thing 'twas anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Tis truth he speakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: This inkindled me, and as Boare,
When he does chaw his foame, predicts some mischiefe,
So my bended front fore-told his ruine,
Forth I drew my sword, and sheathed it
Within his breast, what else is added,
He's a Jew averres, and falser than a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: See, see the Ages wickednesse: can it be possible?
SP.P: O miserable time, when men make no more reckoning of their soules! Fye, fye, Francisco, thinke upon your end, and whither you must goe. Most reverend Fathers, observe you this his con∣tumacy: I shall I feare be forc'd to speak what in my heart till now I chested, and rib'd in, because mine oath, 'twas not my wil hath heare constrained me to expose his blame, my soule had vowed to hide; Note into malice how he throwes himselfe, and would staine my reputation with a calumnious lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Art thou a man, or something else; oh foole, foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Is this possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Give eare unto thy sentece.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I must, in—

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: Did not I say he's mad, starke raving mad, away with him. The man's alive that's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: Yes, they supt together: I love this fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Your Grace shall doe well to punish this saucy groom.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You are a most pernicious damn'd villaine, and your soule knowes it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Come, sir, depart, & rave not, or I shall see you whipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Good Father pardon; pardon mighty Duke, pardon An∣tonio, cause of this disquiet. Lod. Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: By this light he supt with him indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: It is not so, this cannot be.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.L: Is there no mountaine nigh to fall on me, no roten house?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I know not whether I may call thee sonne, or rest in doubt for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: I am Antonio, and I was your son, when I left Venice last.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Is no man here amaz'd but onely I?

SP.SPEAKER: Anto.
SP.L: My deare Phemone!

SP.SPEAKER: Phem.
SP.L: Were you the Shepheard?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: You see chaste Cornelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Was ever man so blest?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Nay, come Francisco, I must have your hand: I can as well forgive, as I can love; and nothing more than both: good Crissippus, my old friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: You have bin a stranger Signior; but I'me glad 'tis thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Whither away: stay him officers; wee have not done with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Wither shall I runne to hide my selfe?
What Climate, or what Region? Pardon greatest Prince.
Pardon grave Fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Against that prayer kneele I:
No pardon Prince, as thou dost hope for blisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Grant him a halter; nothing else good Duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: Give him his liberty: Art thou so impudent to pleade for mercy, and beg of me, having committed such a capitall tres∣passe here in my view?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Though what I speake, with some additions, I have done and more, and he more false has plaid, than I have said, blot his offences: be propitious Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Though the greatest sufferance fell on my part, I here ac∣quit him, and beseech for mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Yet be compendious, and possesse this presence, what cause thou hadst that tempted thee so badly to seek my ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: The Devill and his Angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: O fie Ioretzo.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: How Ioretzo? not the sonne of that pernitious traytor, had plotted with Lamunes for summes of gold to burn our City?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: He's dead, and suffered for the same offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L:
When brought the toad forth other than himselfe, un∣lesse
'twere something worse?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Forget his Fathers faults: be pittifull.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.P: He that prayes next in his behalfe, by heaven friends not himself, and is mine enemy: We have too long suffered such Weeds as these to flourish in our soyle: No more the bosome of this earth of ours, shall (like a mother) lend her fruitlesse en∣crease, to cherish those would bane her: The sword of justice cut the justice off that keeps it sheath'd to such: His deeds were shamefull, his rewards be so, and quittance his desert: Sare on his brow in letters cappitall, the name of knave, that all behold may reade him what he is, and hate him in the sight: His next doome is this; after three daies we charge thee on thy life, never set foote more in thy Native Climate.
SP.L: So, beare him to his torture, speech is vaine:
For what is said there's nothing can restraine.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Most worthy Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Ile be honester while I live for this trick.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Can you forgive mine injury, Antonio?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: As freely as I hope to be forgiven; and crave no more amends, but onely this you'le call me brother, and make Phemo∣ne mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: I need not make what's made, take and enjoy her that hath vow'd to be none but yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Thy hand Arbaces, our quarrell's or'e, we'le no fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Fight, yes: I hope we shall find something else to doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Daughter I have done thee wrong too; but Ile seeke for∣givenesse when we have more leasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: This day breeds wonders: by what accident scapt you of your wounds?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Here stands the meanes, whom I must ever tender with respect, as with my full proceedings you shall heare, when none can interrupt.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.P: Francisco, henceforth know your vertuous wife, & prize her as a jewell: I have heard the world speake well of her, and those unmatch'd wish they may have your fortunes. Lodwicke where's the dumbe shew you promis'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.P:
Even ready my Lord; but may be cald a motion: for puppits wil speak but such corrupt language, you'le never under∣stand without an interpreter, or a short plot; which I have drawn
thus—Now the motion followes.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: What not divulge: yes, yes, I will divulge.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: The jealous Doctor: I have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: Doe me right, sweet Duke, doe me right.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: What art?

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.L: A foole, a physitian, a maintainer of whoredome, with a poxe to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Duk.
SP.L: Then Medice cura teipsum; more knave than foole, the plot's false drawne else: away with em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come sir, depart.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: Purge mee Duke, purge me, or let my wife take out my corrupted braines, and rince them in a Cucking-stoole: I come Skimmington, I come.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Vallentius you must take some order for the Doctors cure: he befriended you in as great a courtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: Trot on afore: is the Corne-cutter come yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: The Horne-cutter is come, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Stult.
SP.L: On, on to the Leaguer then: I am ashamed to show my head amongst Animalls: on to the Leaguer.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: This is a Monster of your making, Lodwicke, buy him a Cap-case to hide up his hornes in, for shame o'th' world.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Come we are both—

DIV1.STAGE: A great Hubub and noise, a ringing of basons, a great many Boyes before, and Julio drawne in a Cart.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Boy.
SP.L: He comes, he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Boy.
SP.L: Where doth he come? hee is rather drawne hither like a Bare to a stake.

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Boy.
SP.L: What in a Coach?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Boy.
SP.P: Nay, rather in an open Charriot: and yet it cannot bee properly called a Chariot, because it runnes but on two Wheeles.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Boy.
SP.L: Roome for him there: for I am sure hee had rather any here had his roome than his company.

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Boy.
SP.L: Silence there; you in the Docket there, let but one speake in the Court at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.L: Noverint universi,
It is the Dukes mercy;
And the condition of my Obligation,
To make my recantation,
That I within bound,
Should give reasons profound,
Why (much against my heart)
I thus ride in a Cart.
SP.P: Nay, gentlemen, no egges I beseech you: for I love them at this time, neither raw, roasted, nor rotten. For should they hit me on the breast, they would goe cleane against my stomacke.

DIV1.STAGE: Tomaso in a corner of the Gallery.

SP.SPEAKER: Tom.
SP.L: You Phaeton.
Is that your Father Phoebus his Chariot, and will he allow you never a Boxe to sit in?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: No juglers Boxe, Ile assure thee friend: for here's neither passe, nor repasse, I stand here you see for an example, And could wish all these good people to follow it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lod.
SP.L: Who's that, Bootes mounted in his Charles waine? doth he cry Pippings, Carrets, or Turneps?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: You are deceived, Signior: rather Bread, and Meate, as Pye-crust, bones, and fragments out of the Ludgate mans basket: Nay, hold your hands, I beseech you Gentlemen, and use your tongues and spare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Stul.
SP.L: Well, he stands heare but for a shew, and I am sure I suf∣fered for it really and indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Beare witnesse my Masters, that is the maine malefactor indeed, and I stand here for a show: Ile goe no further than his owne confession.

SP.SPEAKER: Country fel.
SP.P: They talke of Cheaters, here is a twenty shil∣lings peece that I put into my mouth, let any Cheater in Christendome cousen me of this, and carry it away cleanly, and Ile not only forgive him, but hugge him and imbrace him for it, and say he is a very Hocus Pocus indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: What said that fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Pusse.
SP.L: He saith he hath a peece in his mouth, that all Europe shall not cheate him of.

SP.SPEAKER: Julio.
SP.P: I have markt him, 'tis mine owne: and notwithstan∣ding all this melancholy we'le spend it at night in Wine and Musicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Count. fel.
SP.P: Hee that can plucke this peece out of my jawes, spight of my teeth, and I keepe my mouth fast shut, Ile say hee is more than a Cheater, and a Doctor Faustus, or Mephostophilus at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Puss.
SP.L: Dost heare how he brags?

SP.SPEAKER: Jullio.
SP.L: 'Tis mine own I warrant thee.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Count.
SP.L: But what's become of my horse?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Count.
SP.L: And what's become of my load of hay?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: May I eate hay with your horse, if they were not both done neatly and cleanly. But Gentlemen, and the rest, you see I am at this present your pittifull spectacle. I lookt once within this twelve month, not to have been mounted in such state: but no man knows what preferment hee is born to. You see I have hitherto sayled through this great storme without soyling my Suite, spoyling my Ruffe, or spattering my Beaver: thanks to these kinde spectators.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: But Master Fast and Loose; doe you remember what a slippery trick you served Master Doctor and us?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: And was it not fairely done Master Sergeant, to teach you how to disgest the wearing of a Surplice, before you came to stand in a white sheet.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serg.
SP.L: Well now you are at your journies end: May it please you to alight for your ease?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Withall my heart: and if either you or any of my accu∣sers be weary with following me on foot, the Room is now emp∣ty, I will give him leave to ride in my place. Hee seems to fall into a passion. Yet when I doe but think of this disaster, it draws teares from mine eyes.
SP.L: He draws his handkerchiefe (as to wipe his eyes) just before the Country fellow, and scatters some small mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Country fellow.
SP.L: Sir, you have (I think) let fall some mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Thanks honest friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Count. fel.
SP.L: What do you look for? I can assure you here is all that fell.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L:
Nay, sure I had more mony? 'tis not in my handker∣chief,
nor in my pockets, I have examined them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Serg.
SP.L: Why, what do you want sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: A piece, a piece, and had it now, just now; sure whilst I was so high pearcht none could dive so low into my pocket, it was sure as I lighted, and dropt from mee, just as I drew my handkerchief.

SP.SPEAKER: Puss.
SP.L: Some such thing I saw fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Pray who were they that stoopt?

SP.SPEAKER: Serg.
SP.L: I saw none stoop but this Country fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Then sir, I must demand this piece of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Count. fellow.
SP.L: Of me? I professe I tooke up but two shillings and six pence, and that I gave into your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: But I professe that one of them was a piece, and never came into my hand, and that I must demand of you: say did no body stoop but hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Serg.
SP.L: None I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Thou art still my honest Sergeant.

SP.SPEAKER: Puss.
SP.L: That fellow hath something in his mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Count. fel.
SP.L: Yes my tongue and my teeth, and what of all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Puss.
SP.L: Nay, something else sure, for hee is not troubled with the Mumps, and yet see how one side of his cheeks bumps out.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: I am afraid, we shall finde him a Cheater.

SP.SPEAKER: Serg.
SP.L: Sirrah know I am an Officer, I charge you open your mouth, and let us see what you have in it, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Count. fel.
SP.L: Well sir, I have a twenty shillings piece, what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Serg.
SP.L: And this man misseth a twenty shilling piece out of his pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: Plead well Sergeant and thou shalt have thy see.

SP.SPEAKER: Count. fel.
SP.L: Well, there it is, what can you make of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Marry twenty shillings good and lawfull currant mo∣ny, Puss, was not this the piece that I put in my pocket this mor∣ning?

SP.SPEAKER: Puss.
SP.L: I know it by that mark.

SP.SPEAKER: Serg.
SP.L: And she's witnesse sufficient in conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.P: Doe you see Gentlemen. I am here brought to publike penance for a Cheater, and here's a plain fellow that (it seems) in his simplicity would out-doe me: if I be thus censured meer∣ly for suspicion; shall hee scape free that is taken in the very action?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: No, no, mount him, mount him.

SP.SPEAKER: Count. fel.
SP.P: Nay, by your favour Gentlemen, I have driven a Cart often for my pleasure, and would bee loth to ride in one now for my punishment. It is penance enough for mee to part with my peece, which cannot be more currant of Coine, then his is Arrant for Knavery.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio.
SP.L: He's gone, I am still here, now Gentlemen,
If heretofore there hath been any Doll,
Any bold Beachum, and any Cut-purse Moll.
Any Bawd fat with wealth, or with care meager,
That spends her time in Garrison or Leager,
Grace me so farre to say, that of a Cheater
Though some have been more grave; scarce any greater,
But Gentlemen; what need we more repeating?
Knowing, that even in all Trades there is cheating?
Tis common both in buying and in selling,
In all Commerce; nay, even in mony telling.
Tis frequent 'twixt the Pander and the Whore,
We our selves finde it at the Play-house doore.
And though (for an example) here I stand,
I am not all the Cheaters in the land.
Some here (no question) know it but I vow,
(They what they please) I will cheat none of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Duke.
SP.L: We understand their humours,
And the cause of their distempers;
And have too long suffered such weeds
As these to flourish in our soyle,
But now no longer shall this earth of ours,
Like a inde Mother lend her fruits increase,
To cherish those would eclipse her worth.
But those whose aymes and acts are imitable,
Crown with green Garlands, and with Bowls brim'd full.
Musique proclaime a generall Festivall,
A Jubile of joy and mirth to all:
May love and truth, never like comfort misse,
Nor Knave in Grain, scape a reward like this.
